orig: translate old to modern: Like one of two contending in a prize, That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether those peals of praise be his or no; So, thrice fair lady, stand I, even so; As doubtful whether what I see be true, Until confirm'd, sign'd, ratified by you.
target: Like one of two contenders for a prize, That thinks he has done well in people's eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether those peals of praise are his or not; So, three times beautiful lady, I stand I, even like this, As doubtful of whether what I see is true, Until it is confirmed, signed, and ratified by you.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me my armor.
target: Give me my amour.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?
target: Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice’s love?

orig: translate old to modern: But are my brother’s powers set forth?
target: Have my brother-in-law’s troops been mobilized?

orig: translate old to modern: He hath, my lord.
target: He has, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: But, like a sickness, did I loathe this food; But, as in health, come to my natural taste, Now I do wish it, love it, long for it, And will for evermore be true to it.
target: But, like a sickness, I hated the taste this food; But, now healthy, my natural tastes restored, Now I wish it, love it, long for it, And will for evermore be true to it.

orig: translate old to modern: How does the Queen?
target: How is the Queen?

orig: translate old to modern: Hamlet return'd shall know you are come home.
target: When Hamlet returns, he shall know you’re Home.

orig: translate old to modern: What dost thou profess?
target: What’s your profession?

orig: translate old to modern: What is the news?
target: What’s the news?

orig: translate old to modern: Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest.
target: Get them in here—Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest.

orig: translate old to modern: An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me.
target: And if anything important happens, find me and let me know.

orig: translate old to modern: Not I.
target: Not me.

orig: translate old to modern: O, well done!
target: O, well done!

orig: translate old to modern: The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour To visit me.—You know your office, brother.
target: The Prince and Claudio are supposed to be here by now.—You know your job, brother.

orig: translate old to modern: Break we our watch up; and by my advice Let us impart what we have seen tonight Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life, This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
target: Let’s break up our watch, and I think We should tell all we have seen tonight To young Hamlet, for, I swear on my life, This spirit, silent to us, will speak to him.

orig: translate old to modern: What should I do?
target: What should I do?

orig: translate old to modern: Our severed navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sealike.
target: Our tattered navy has reassembled and set sail, as formidable as the sea itself.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy letters have transported me beyond This ignorant present, and I feel now The future in the instant.
target: Your letters have transported me beyond This ignorant present, and I now feel The future in the instant.

orig: translate old to modern: Are you of good or evil?
target: are you of good or evil?

orig: translate old to modern: Ere I ope his letter, I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.
target: Before I open his letter, Please tell me how my good friend is doing.

orig: translate old to modern: Ophelia, walk you here.
target: Ophelia, you walk here.

orig: translate old to modern: to Sebastian] True, Of that there's none, or little.
target: There's none, or little of that.

orig: translate old to modern: Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speak’st In better phrase and matter than thou didst.
target: It seems to me that your voice has changed, and that your speech is more elegant than it used to be.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
target: Why, he won’t wake up till Judgment Day.

orig: translate old to modern: Not that I love you not.
target: Not that I don’t love you.

orig: translate old to modern: You are too officious In her behalf that scorns your services.
target: You are too over-zealous On her behalf that rejects your services.

orig: translate old to modern: Be choked with such another emphasis!
target: May you choke on any other sentiments like that!

orig: translate old to modern: Whip me, ye devils, From the possession of this heavenly sight!
target: Whip me, you devils, From the possession of this heavenly sight!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my good lord.
target: Yes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: This grief is crowned with consolation.
target: But in this way, grief and comfort appear together.

orig: translate old to modern: If it were done when ’tis done, then ’twere well It were done quickly.
target: If this deed were done when it is done, then it would be better If it were done quickly.

orig: translate old to modern: To do thus I learned of thee.
target: I learned to do this from you.

orig: translate old to modern: We’ll overreach the graybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Litio, All for my master’s sake, Lucentio.
target: We’ll outwit them all—that old geezer, Gremio; the suspicious father, Minola; the prim musician lover, Litio—all for the sake of my master, Lucentio.

orig: translate old to modern: I am glad to see you well.
target: I am glad to see you well.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?
target: Shall I go get your nightgown?

orig: translate old to modern: One aloof stand sentinel.
target: One of you, stand sentinel over there.

orig: translate old to modern: Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meet’st the fellow.
target: Then keep your vow, fellow, when you meet the man.

orig: translate old to modern: Each heart in Rome does love and pity you.
target: Every heart in Rome loves and pities you.

orig: translate old to modern: Doth thy other mouth call me?
target: Does your other mouth call me?

orig: translate old to modern: An if he be not fought withal, my lord, Let us not live in France.
target: And if he advances unopposed, my lord, let us abandon France.

orig: translate old to modern: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—for my duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.
target: Please forgive me if I’m mistaken, my lord—but I can’t keep quiet when I think you’re being insulted.

orig: translate old to modern: The tyrant custom, most grave senators, Hath made the flinty and steel couch of war My thrice driven bed of down.
target: The dictator, custom, very grave senators, Has made the stone and steel couch of war My feather bed three times.

orig: translate old to modern: Hark, hark!
target: Listen, listen!

orig: translate old to modern: He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.
target: Arrest him: he’s a friend of the duke of Alençon’s.

orig: translate old to modern: Let’s ha' ’t, good Grumio.
target: Well, let’s have it, Grumio.

orig: translate old to modern: Hers you are.
target: You belong to her.

orig: translate old to modern: Tempt him not so too far.
target: Don’t push him too far.

orig: translate old to modern: I thought the king had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwall.
target: I thought the king preferred the Duke of Albany to the Duke of Cornwall.

orig: translate old to modern: Say boldly.
target: Speak confidently.

orig: translate old to modern: The duke my father loved his father dearly.
target: You’ll fight with him eventually, and  The duke, my father, loved his father very much.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, good my lord— It is but foolery; but it is such a kind of gain-giving as would perhaps trouble a woman.
target: No, my good lord, It’s only foolishness, but it is such a kind of misgiving as would maybe trouble a woman.

orig: translate old to modern: Almost at odds with morning, which is which.
target: Almost the middle of the night.

orig: translate old to modern: I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her.
target: I am satisfied, as long as the maiden cities you talk of come with her.

orig: translate old to modern: The town is beseeched, and the trumpet call us to the breach, and we talk and, be Chrish, do nothing, ’tis shame for us all.
target: The town is besieged, and the trumpet calls us to the gap, and we talk and do nothing, by Christ.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord and brother, God save you.
target: My lord and brother, God save you.

orig: translate old to modern: It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid to consign to.
target: It’s a lot to ask of a maiden.

orig: translate old to modern: These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.
target: These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir.
target: You’re wrong, sir, very wrong.

orig: translate old to modern: Did he never make you laugh?
target: What, he never made you laugh?

orig: translate old to modern: They are then excused, my lord, when they see not what they do.
target: They’re forgiven, then, if they don’t see what they’re doing.

orig: translate old to modern: Then yield thee, coward, And live to be the show and gaze o’ the time.
target: Then surrender, you coward, And live to be the center of attention of the times.

orig: translate old to modern: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
target: Let him sink there so the sea will cover him!

orig: translate old to modern: Sweet, do not scorn her so.
target: Sweet, don’t scorn her like that.

orig: translate old to modern: O, horrible!
target: O, horrible!

orig: translate old to modern: To bed, to bed, to bed.
target: To bed, to bed, to bed.

orig: translate old to modern: Did he not say my brother was fled?
target: Didn’t he say my brother has run away?

orig: translate old to modern: Would they were clysterpipes for your sake!
target: I wish they were hypodermics for your sake!

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, ass.
target: Hello, you idiot.

orig: translate old to modern: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
target: James Tyrrel—and your most obedient subject.

orig: translate old to modern: to Gonzalo] Though this island seem to be [to Gonzalo] Though this island seem to be desert,— [to Sebastian] Ha, ha, ha!
target: Though this island seems to be deserted,— Ha, ha, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?
target: On me, though I am barely half the man that Edward was?

orig: translate old to modern: Ingrateful fox, ’tis he.
target: That’s him.

orig: translate old to modern: Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle, That so approve the Moor!
target: Thank you, the valiant of this warlike isle, That so approve the Moor!

orig: translate old to modern: I learned it in England, where indeed they are most potent in potting.
target: I learned it in England, where, indeed, they are very powerful drinkers.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
target: Hortensio

orig: translate old to modern: That will I do.
target: That I will do.

orig: translate old to modern: Look on the tragic loading of this bed; This is thy work.
target: Look on the tragic load on this bed; This is your work.

orig: translate old to modern: He is returned.
target: Here he comes back.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, my good lord.
target: Well, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Attend those men Our pleasure?
target: Are those men Waiting for us?

orig: translate old to modern: So, prithee, go with me.
target: So, I beg you, go with me.

orig: translate old to modern: Why should calamity be full of words?
target: But give words a chance.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, go to, I will.
target: All right, I will.

orig: translate old to modern: Your reproof is something too round.
target: Your scolding is somewhat overblown.

orig: translate old to modern: He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him.—Enobarbus!
target: He was in a good mood, and then suddenly he started thinking of Rome.

orig: translate old to modern: Give them the foils, young Osric.
target: Give them the swords, young Osric.

orig: translate old to modern: Let him alone, for I remember now How he’s employed.
target: I remember he’s already occupied.

orig: translate old to modern: Even so, Lucilius.
target: Even like that, Lucilius.

orig: translate old to modern: God pardon them that are the cause thereof.
target: God pardon those who are responsible for Clarence’s troubles.

orig: translate old to modern: He cannot be such a monster— Nor is not, sure.
target: He can’t possibly be such a monster— And I’m sure he isn’t.

orig: translate old to modern: Who could refrain, That had a heart to love, and in that heart Courage to make's love known?
target: Who could refrain, That had a heart to love, and in that heart Courage to make his love known?

orig: translate old to modern: He wish'd today our enterprise might thrive.
target: He wished that our undertaking today might thrive.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.
target: My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, sit down, For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
target: Now everyone be seated, as this is the part where we sit and chat as well as eat.

orig: translate old to modern: The hand of little employment hath the daintier sense.
target: The one that doesn’t work has the more delicate sense.

orig: translate old to modern: I wish mine eyes Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find They are inclined to do so.
target: I wish my eyes Would shut up my thoughts by closing: I think They want to do so.

orig: translate old to modern: Besides, I like you not.
target: Besides, I don’t like you.

orig: translate old to modern: They are all welcome.
target: They’re all welcome.— What worries are keeping you From sleeping?

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed, And it portends alone the fall of Antony.
target: You, my earthly moon, are now eclipsed, and that alone foretells my ruin.

orig: translate old to modern: I will, my lord.
target: I will, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, ’tis he.
target: Sadly, it’s the king that’s missing.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, there’s more gold.
target: Well then, here’s more money for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Ere we were two days old at sea, a pirate of very warlike appointment gave us chase.
target: Before we were even at sea for two days, a very nasty looking pirate chased us.

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.
target: Good morning, old Sir Thomas Erpingham!

orig: translate old to modern: And yet my sky shall not want.
target: And yet I’ll still have plenty.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
target: He’s a good-looking young man, and there are a lot of people with him.

orig: translate old to modern: I will but spend a word here in the house And go with you.
target: I will only say one more word here in the house, And I’ll go with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes Baptista.
target: He gives BIONDELLO  Here comes Baptista.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, guiltiness will speak, Though tongues were out of use.
target: No, guiltiness will speak Even if tongues are out of use.

orig: translate old to modern: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.
target: As long as hell and Richard want it.

orig: translate old to modern: Not stingless too.
target: Not stingless too.

orig: translate old to modern: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.
target: You don’t know Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.

orig: translate old to modern: And you.
target: You too.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail, King of Scotland!
target: Hail, King of Scotland!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou say’st the king grows mad.
target: You say the king is losing his mind.

target: Goneril would go crazy if I chose Regan, but it would be hard to get in with Goneril while her husband’s still alive.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, you nod.
target: Don’t ask why.

orig: translate old to modern: dead, Desdemon!
target: dead, Desdemon!

orig: translate old to modern: I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
target: I know I’m not fooling myself, or letting myself get carried away by my imagination, because every clue points to the fact that Lady Olivia loves me.

orig: translate old to modern: The prayers of holy saints and wrongèd souls, Like high-reared bulwarks, stand before our faces.
target: The prayers of saints and those that Richard wronged support us like high-walled fortresses.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore tremble and depart.
target: Therefore, tremble with fear and leave.

orig: translate old to modern: My liege.
target: My liege.

orig: translate old to modern: Say you?
target: What did you say?

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, the Queen would speak with you, and presently.
target: My lord, the queen wants to speak with you right now.

orig: translate old to modern: And I for Rosalind.
target: And like I am for Rosalind.

orig: translate old to modern: It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him, but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires.
target: We were somewhere where I couldn’t pick a fight with him, but I’ve decided to wear it in my cap until I see him again, whereupon I’ll give him a little piece of my mind.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha!
target: Ha!

orig: translate old to modern: You are jealous now That this is from some mistress, some remembrance: No, by my faith, Bianca.
target: You are jealous now That this is from some mistress, some gift.

orig: translate old to modern: It is clean out of the way.
target: It is clean out of the way.

orig: translate old to modern: Horatio says 'tis but our fantasy, And will not let belief take hold of him Touching this dreaded sight, twice seen of us.
target: Horatio says it’s all in our imagination, And doesn’t believe a word we say About this dreaded sight, seen twice by us.

orig: translate old to modern: I tell thee true.
target: I’m telling the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: O, blood, blood, blood!
target: O, blood, Iago, blood!

orig: translate old to modern: I do not know; I am sure I am none such.
target: I don’t know; I am sure I am no one like that.

orig: translate old to modern: I did not see him since.
target: I haven’t seen him recently.

orig: translate old to modern: If chance will have me king, why, chance may crown me Without my stir.
target: If luck wants me to be king, luck may crown me Without my doing anything at all.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, look you now, how unworthy a thing you make of me!
target: Why, look here, at what an unworthy a thing you make of me!

orig: translate old to modern: There's many a beast then in a populous city, And many a civil monster.
target: There's many a beast, then, in a crowded city, And many a civil monster.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue.
target: Come, come, you answer me stupidly.

orig: translate old to modern: The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail, And you are stay'd for.
target: The wind sits in the best part of your sail, And the ship waits for you.

orig: translate old to modern: An’t please your Majesty, ’tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.
target: If it pleases your Majesty, it is the token of a man I must fight with, if he’s still alive.

orig: translate old to modern: My countryman: but yet I know him not.
target: My countryman, but I still don’t know him.

orig: translate old to modern: Katherine the curst!” A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
target: Katherine the shrew!” That’s the worst thing you can call a young woman.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, no, sir.
target: Why, no, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I wish, forbear.
target: I wish you’d be patient.

orig: translate old to modern: Sad, lady!
target: Sad, my lady!

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I know not.
target: No, I know not.

orig: translate old to modern: He says they can do nothing in this kind.
target: He says they can’t do anything like this.

orig: translate old to modern: I should not urge thy duty past thy might; I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
target: I shouldn’t make you do your duty past your strength; I know young bloods look for time of rest.

orig: translate old to modern: Wrench his sword from him.
target: Grab his sword from him.

orig: translate old to modern: O, help me here!
target: O, help me here!

orig: translate old to modern: I have no power upon you.
target: I have no power over you.

orig: translate old to modern: In God’s name, speak.
target: In God’s name, speak.

orig: translate old to modern: God help the noble Claudio!
target: God help Claudio!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my lord.
target: Yes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: My gracious sovereign.
target: My gracious king.

orig: translate old to modern: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.
target: You can be a eunuch, but I’ll be mute.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you doubt that?
target: Do you doubt that?

orig: translate old to modern: Away, away, be gone!
target: Away, away, be gone!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, a tailor, sir.
target: Definitely a tailor, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Good night, good night.
target: Good-night, good-night.

orig: translate old to modern: I was about to protest I loved you.
target: I was about to swear that I loved you.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet that is but a crushed necessity, Since we have locks to safeguard necessaries And pretty traps to catch the petty thieves.
target: But that is a false conclusion, since we have locks to keep our valuables safe and clever traps to catch little thieves.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, as time shall try.
target: Well, time will tell.

orig: translate old to modern: Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon'd; Here is my journey's end, here is my butt And very seamark of my utmost sail.
target: Don’t be afraid although you see me armed, Here is my journey's end, here is my bottom And very sea-mark of my last ship.

orig: translate old to modern: Let him do his spite.
target: Let him do his worse.

orig: translate old to modern: I have offended reputation, A most unnoble swerving.
target: I’ve destroyed my reputation, a most shameful error.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, so I think.
target: Yes, I think that’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement: That God fought for us.
target: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement—that God fought for us.

orig: translate old to modern: Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any.
target: Then there would be two cousins lying sick in bed: one hurt by reasons and the other gone crazy without any.

orig: translate old to modern: As freely, son, as God did give her me.
target: As freely, son, as God gave her to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Upon the king!
target: Upon the king!

orig: translate old to modern: I am tame, sir.
target: I am calm, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee—and I’ll pay thee bounteously— Conceal me what I am, and be my aid For such disguise as haply shall become The form of my intent.
target: Please—and I’ll pay you plenty for this—help me conceal my identity, and find me the right disguise so I can look the way I want.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, what did I?
target: Why, what did I do?

orig: translate old to modern: She will sit you—you heard my daughter tell you how.
target: She will have a seat—you heard my daughter tell you how.

orig: translate old to modern: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
target: I’ll be gentle and mild.

orig: translate old to modern: Jove, Jove, this shepherd’s passion Is much upon my fashion.
target: By God!

orig: translate old to modern: I am mightily abused.
target: I’ve been tricked.

orig: translate old to modern: I see thee yet, in form as palpable As this which now I draw.
target: I still see you, in form as evident to my touch As the one I now draw.

orig: translate old to modern: Most grave Brabantio, In simple and pure soul I come to you.
target: Very grave Brabantio, I come to you in simple and pure soul.

orig: translate old to modern: I see thee compass'd with thy kingdom's pearl That speak my salutation in their minds, Whose voices I desire aloud with mine: Hail, King of Scotland!
target: I see you surrounded by the finest nobles in the kingdom That speak my greetings by their thoughts, Whose voices I want to hear loudly with mine: Hail, King of Scotland!

orig: translate old to modern: Touching our person, seek we no revenge, But we our kingdom’s safety must so tender, Whose ruin you have sought, that to her laws We do deliver you.
target: I seek no revenge for myself, but so dearly do I hold the safety of my kingdom, which you sought to destroy, that you must be punished according to her laws.

orig: translate old to modern: I do love it better than laughing.
target: I like it better than laughing.

orig: translate old to modern: Edmund, seek him out, wind me into him, I pray you.
target: Edmund, go find him.

orig: translate old to modern: Why should I, Mother?
target: Why should I, mother?

orig: translate old to modern: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista’s youngest daughter.
target: I’d second your wish if it automatically meant that Lucentio could have Baptista’s youngest daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: Dismiss me?
target: Dismiss me?

orig: translate old to modern: No more with me.
target: No more than twenty-five.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not Barbason; you cannot conjure me.
target: I am not some fiend of hell: you can’t get rid of me with spells.

orig: translate old to modern: Fut, I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing.
target: I would have been what I am even if the most virginal star in the heavens had twinkled at my conception.

orig: translate old to modern: Wondrous heavy.
target: Amazingly sleepy!

orig: translate old to modern: I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
target: I’ll give you the title to that ship and its treasure.

orig: translate old to modern: Perchance he will not mind me.
target: I'll fall down flat; Maybe he won’t notice me.

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing.
target: What are you  Nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: I am no child, no babe.
target: I am not a child or an infant.

orig: translate old to modern: Metellus Cimber?
target: Metellus Cimber?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I can gleek upon occasion.
target: No, I can only make a joke for a specific occasion.

orig: translate old to modern: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
target: Father, wife, friends—farewell!

orig: translate old to modern: Now, by two-headed Janus, Nature hath fram'd strange fellows in her time: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes, And laugh, like parrots, at a bag-piper; And other of such vinegar aspect, That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile, Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
target: Now, looking at both sides, Nature has made strange fellows in her time: Some that will peep through their eyes forever, And laugh like parrots at a bag-piper, And the others of such sour disposition That they'll never smile Although a wise old man swears that the joke is funny.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt find That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think I have cast off for ever.
target: And then you’ll see that despite what you thought, I’ll be as powerful as I was before.

orig: translate old to modern: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
target: I think we know whose fancy handwriting that was.

orig: translate old to modern: There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
target: Lock yourself in and send him word that you’re dead.

orig: translate old to modern: Behold!
target: Behold!

target: If it’s bad, Why has it given me promise of success, That began with a truth?

target: Night is approaching.

target: Yes, so, God be with you!

target: The more fool you for betting on my loyalty.

target: Lovely, most lovely Katherine, will you agree to teach a soldier the words that would recommend his love-suit to a gentle heart like yours?

target: In terms of choice, I am not only led By the nice direction of a maiden's eyes; Besides, the lottery of my destiny Doesn’t give me the right to choose voluntarily; But, if my father had not restricted me And controlled me by his wit, to give myself As his wife to the one who wins me by that means I told you, you yourself, renowned Prince, would then Stand as fair as any other man I have looked on yet For my affection.

orig: translate old to modern: O, say!
target: O, tell me!

orig: translate old to modern: when they do choose, They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
target: When they choose, They have the wisdom to lose by their senses.

target: Corporal Nym, be a man and put away your sword.

target: Come to my cave and tell me the rest of your story.—Good old man, you are as welcome here as your master is.

target: And when she is peevish and perverse, sullen, sour, and disobedient to his honest wishes, what is she but a loathsome, warlike rebel and an ungrateful traitor to her loving lord?

target: Oh, let me remember what happened to Hastings and hurry to

target: Do you intend to sink us?

target: I was afraid he was only trifling with you And meant to wreck you, but curse my jealousy!

orig: translate old to modern: Affection?
target: Affection!

orig: translate old to modern: How does my good Lord Hamlet?
target: How does my good Lord Hamlet?

target: I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy.

orig: translate old to modern: I have not scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs; for it hath been said, ‘As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground.’ And it shall be said so again, while Stephano breathes at nostrils.
target: I have not escaped drowning to be afraid now of your four legs; because it has been said, “As proper a man as ever went on four legs can’t make him give ground”: and it shall be said so again, while Stephano still breathes through His nostrils.

target: Captain Macmorris, if you take my words in some way other than how they were meant, see, I’ll have to think you’re not treating me with the good will you ought to, see, since I am as good a man as yourself, both in the practice of war and in my country of origin and in other respects.

orig: translate old to modern: Publius, good cheer, There is no harm intended to your person, Nor to no Roman else.
target: We don’t intend to harm you, Or any other Roman.

orig: translate old to modern: A pair of stocks, you rogue!
target: You thug!

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, go with us.
target: Please come with me.

orig: translate old to modern: But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak; And do not doubt, right noble princes both, But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case.
target: But, my good lord, the words of you and Lord Buckingham are as trustworthy to me as if I had seen and heard him speak myself.

orig: translate old to modern: And therefore as a stranger give it welcome.
target: And therefore, as a stranger, welcome it.

orig: translate old to modern: Poor knave, I blame thee not, thou art o'erwatch'd.
target: Poor knave, I don’t blame You; you’ve been wake up too long.

orig: translate old to modern: most ungrateful maid!
target: Most ungrateful maid!

orig: translate old to modern: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup; I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
target: Fill the cup, Lucius, until the wine overflows; I can’t drink too much of Brutus' friendship.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, I’ll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
target: Now, I’ll swear to the opposite—that the pancakes were rotten, and the mustard was fine—but even so, the knight wasn’t lying.

orig: translate old to modern: When you do find him, or alive or dead, He will be found like Brutus, like himself.
target: When you do find him, or alive or dead, He’ll be found like Brutus, like himself.

orig: translate old to modern: One of them showed me a ring, that he had of your daughter for a monkey.
target: One of them showed me a ring that he accepted from your daughter as payment for a monkey.

orig: translate old to modern: At a word, I am not.
target: In short, I’m not.

orig: translate old to modern: Thriftless ambition, that wilt ravin up Thine own life's means!
target: Thriftless ambition, that will plunder Your own life's means!

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Cinna; now, Metellus; what, Trebonius, I have an hour's talk in store for you; Remember that you call on me today; Be near me, that I may remember you.
target: Remember that you call on me today; Be near me so that I may remember you.

orig: translate old to modern: One more, one more; Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee, And love thee after.
target: One more, one more; Be like this when you are dead, and I will kill you, And love you after.

orig: translate old to modern: But, for true need— You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need.
target: Oh, gods, give me patience!

orig: translate old to modern: This is most certain that I shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected.
target: This news is absolutely true: Mark Antony is expected to arrive in Rome at any hour now.

orig: translate old to modern: I will do't, my lord.
target: I will do it, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you know me, father?
target: Don’t you know me, father?

orig: translate old to modern: I love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he’s full of matter.
target: I love to argue with him when he’s having one of these fits, because then he always has a lot to say.

orig: translate old to modern: In cases of defense ’tis best to weigh The enemy more mighty than he seems.
target: When it comes to defense, it’s best to assume that the enemy is more powerful than he seems.

orig: translate old to modern: Heaven bless us!
target: Heaven bless us!

orig: translate old to modern: Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?
target: Did he express any dissatisfaction with you, either in his words or his face?

orig: translate old to modern: I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of nature—”  I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s mistress.
target: I once wrote a sonnet in his praise which began, “Wonder of nature—” I have heard a sonnet to one’s mistress that began like that.

orig: translate old to modern: Can you deny all this?
target: Is there anything inaccurate in that?

orig: translate old to modern: Well met, Corporal Nym.
target: Good to see you, Corporal Nym.

orig: translate old to modern: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to me.
target: Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio’s happiness will be like medicine to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, General.
target: Good morning, General.

orig: translate old to modern: O villain!
target: O villain!

orig: translate old to modern: I wish you all joy of the worm.
target: I hope you are pleased with the snake.

orig: translate old to modern: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
target: Our poor father, Clarence!

orig: translate old to modern: Will ’t please your highness walk?
target: Would your highness like to take a walk?

orig: translate old to modern: Come, let me have a bigger.
target: Bring me a bigger one.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, cousin Hero!
target: How are you, Hero?

orig: translate old to modern: My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.
target: I believe it.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha, they pluck out mine eyes!
target: Ha, they pluck out my eyes!

orig: translate old to modern: I know you what you are, And like a sister am most loath to call Your faults as they are named.
target: I know you for what you really are, but as your sister I’m reluctant to criticize you.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me see—what think you of falling in love?
target: Let me see—what do you think about falling in love?

orig: translate old to modern: Young boys and girls Are level now with men.
target: Young boys and girls are equal to men.

orig: translate old to modern: What was it you told me of today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
target: What was it that you told me today—that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

orig: translate old to modern: My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that, look your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alençon.
target: My liege, this man is a villain and a traitor, who—see, your Grace—has struck the glove which your Majesty took from Alençon’s helmet.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, come, Kate, come.
target: Oh, come on now, Kate.

orig: translate old to modern: My brother shall know of it.
target: My brother shall know of it.

orig: translate old to modern: Be thy mouth or black or white,  Do-de, de-de.
target: Whether your mouth is black or white, Do-dee, dee-dee da.

orig: translate old to modern: Call forth my household servants.
target: Call out my household servants.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is my love?
target: Where is my lovely bride?

orig: translate old to modern: So is it, if thou knew'st our purposes.
target: So it is, if you knew our reasons.

orig: translate old to modern: Kill me tomorrow; let me live tonight!
target: Kill me tomorrow; let me live tonight!

orig: translate old to modern: My sword is drawn.
target: I have drawn my sword.

orig: translate old to modern: O weary reckoning!
target: O weary calculations!

orig: translate old to modern: This prophecy Merlin shall make, for I live before his time.
target: This is the prophecy that the wizard

orig: translate old to modern: Where’s thy drum?
target: Coward!

orig: translate old to modern: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath; when every drop of blood That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.
target: Swear priests and cowards, and deceitful men, Old feeble dead bodies and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; swear to bad causes that Such creatures as men doubt, but don’t stain The even goodness of our undertaking, or the unsuppressed character of our spirits, To think that our cause and our performance Need oaths, when every drop of blood That every Roman carries, and carries nobly, Is guilty of causing the birth of several bastards, If he breaks the smallest particle Of any promise that he has made.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face.
target: I’ll put on some poor and ragged clothes and smudge my face with dirt.

orig: translate old to modern: I would fain learn to lie.
target: I want to learn how to lie.

orig: translate old to modern: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare.
target: He’s a very dishonest, puny boy, and more cowardly than a rabbit.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me entreat you.
target: As a favor to  Nope.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll fetch some flax and whites of eggs To apply to his bleeding face.
target: I’ll get some cloth and egg whites to bandage his bleeding face.

orig: translate old to modern: And what's he then that says I play the villain?
target: And who’s he, then, that says I play the villain?

orig: translate old to modern: O thou vile king, Give me my father!
target: O you vile king, Give me my father!

orig: translate old to modern: Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre.
target: He’s killed three people, and he’s so furious right now that the only thing that will satisfy him is seeing you die.

orig: translate old to modern: They are of Norway, sir.
target: They are from Norway, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I mean, in a sort.
target: I mean, in a way.

orig: translate old to modern: Wilt thou let him, my lord?
target: Will you let him, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: It hath not appeared.
target: It doesn’t seem so.

orig: translate old to modern: Sit, sir.
target: After you.

orig: translate old to modern: And so will I.
target: And so will I.

orig: translate old to modern: O, reform it altogether!
target: O, overcome them with zeal.

orig: translate old to modern: Aside.
target: Aside.

orig: translate old to modern: Go not my horse the better, I must become a borrower of the night For a dark hour or twain.
target: If my horse doesn’t ride better, I must become a borrower of the night, For a dark hour or two.

orig: translate old to modern: I would out-night you, did no body come; But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
target: I would out-night you, if no one was coming, But, listen, I hear the footsteps of a man.

orig: translate old to modern: Amen.
target: Amen.

orig: translate old to modern: No, Caesar shall not.
target: No, Caesar shall not.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.
target: No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it.

orig: translate old to modern: Was this ambition?
target: Was this ambition?

orig: translate old to modern: Tom, away!
target: Let’s go, Tom.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, behold How pomp is followed!
target: Oh, just see what happens after the pageantry is over!

orig: translate old to modern: Sing it.
target: Then sing it.

orig: translate old to modern: the life?
target: The life?

orig: translate old to modern: But first I will release the fairy queen.
target: But first, I will release the fairy queen.

orig: translate old to modern: I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
target: Sometimes all I want to do is see plays and go out dancing.

orig: translate old to modern: Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret.
target: It’s time to hide, wretched Margaret.

orig: translate old to modern: What is this, That rises like the issue of a king, And wears upon his baby brow the round And top of sovereignty?
target: What is this That rises like the heirs of a king, And wears upon his baby brow the Golden crown of a king?

orig: translate old to modern: At least we'll die with harness on our back.
target: At least we'll die with armor on our back.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, the honest men.
target: Why, the honest men.

orig: translate old to modern: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman.
target: There’s a lot to learn when a fool recites the words of a madman.

orig: translate old to modern: Our gracious brother, I will go with them.
target: Gracious brother, I will go with them.

orig: translate old to modern: Stand aside.
target: Stand aside.

orig: translate old to modern: So please my lord the duke, and all the court To quit the fine for one half of his goods; I am content, so he will let me have The other half in use, to render it, Upon his death, unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter; Two things provided more,—that for this favour, He presently become a Christian; The other, that he do record a gift, Here in the court, of all he dies possess'd, Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.
target: So if it pleases my lord, the Duke, and all the court To set the fine for one half of his goods, I am content, as long as he will let me have The other half to use, to give it, On his death, to the gentleman That lately stole his daughter: Two things more, that, for this favor, He presently becomes a Christian; The other, that he records a gift, Here in the court, of everything he has when he dies To his son, Lorenzo, and his daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet.
target: I knew him when he would’ve walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket.

orig: translate old to modern: To my sick soul, as sin's true nature is, Each toy seems prologue to some great amiss.
target: To my sick soul, such as sin's true nature is, Each new thing seems to be the prelude to some great harm.

orig: translate old to modern: Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,” And word it, prithee, piteously.
target: Say the last word I spoke was “Antony,” and please word it pathetically.

orig: translate old to modern: Knock Knock Hark!
target: Listen, more knocking.

orig: translate old to modern: I believe drink gave thee the lie last night.
target: I believe drink gave you the lie last night.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.
target: Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.

orig: translate old to modern: O, how I love thee!
target: Oh, how I love you!

orig: translate old to modern: O Isis, ’tis impossible.
target: Oh, Isis, that’s impossible.

orig: translate old to modern: My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then.
target: That was when I was young and inexperienced and didn’t know what passion was.

orig: translate old to modern: The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love cause.
target: This world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time not one man has ever actually died from love.

orig: translate old to modern: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will.
target: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will.

orig: translate old to modern: I never did repent for doing good, Nor shall not now; for in companions That do converse and waste the time together, Whose souls do bear an equal yoke of love, There must be needs a like proportion Of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit; Which makes me think, that this Antonio, Being the bosom lover of my lord, Must needs be like my lord.
target: I never did regret doing good, And I won’t now; because in companions That talk and waste the time together, Whose souls bear an equal burden of love, There must be a sharing of things like proportion Of limbs, manners, and spirit, Which makes me think that this Antonio, Being the closest friend of my lord, Must be like my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, sit thee down upon this flowery bed, While I thy amiable cheeks do coy, And stick musk-roses in thy sleek smooth head, And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.
target: Come, sit down on this flowery bed, While I play with your amiable cheeks, And stick musk-roses in your sleek smooth head, And kiss your fair large ears, my gentle joy.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, sir, get you in.
target: Well, sir, go inside.

orig: translate old to modern: One word more, honest neighbors.
target: One more thing, good gentlemen.

orig: translate old to modern: In mine ignorance Your skill shall, like a star i' the darkest night, Stick fiery off indeed.
target: In my ignorance, Your skill shall, like a star in the darkest night, be shown to its fiery advantage indeed.

orig: translate old to modern: Frailty, thy name is woman— A little month, or ere those shoes were old With which she follow'd my poor father's body Like Niobe, all tears—why she, even she— O God!
target: Weakness, your name is woman — A little month, even before those shoes with which she Followed my poor father's body were old, she was Totally inconsolable, all tears, why she, even she— O God!

orig: translate old to modern: Uncle, I must come forth.
target: Uncle, I must come out.

orig: translate old to modern: Twice then the trumpets sounded, And there I left him tranced.
target: Then I heard the trumpets blow twice, and left him there in a trance.

orig: translate old to modern: If, sir, perchance She have restrained the riots of your followers, 'Tis on such ground and to such wholesome end As clears her from all blame.
target: If she restrained your rowdy knights, she had such a good reason that you can’t blame her for it.

orig: translate old to modern: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.
target: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward, And the beholders of this frantic play, Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.
target: Your Clarence, who stabbed my Edward, is also dead.

orig: translate old to modern: No more of drowning, do you hear?
target: No more about drowning, do you hear?

orig: translate old to modern: The foul fiend follows me!
target: The devil’s after me!

orig: translate old to modern: If Hamlet give the first or second hit, Or quit in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements their ordnance fire; The King shall drink to Hamlet's better breath, And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark's crown have worn.
target: If Hamlet gives the first or second hit, Or quits in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements fire their ammunition, The king shall drink to Hamlet's better breath, And in the cup he shall throw a pearl, Richer than that which four successive kings Have worn in Denmark's crown.

orig: translate old to modern: If I do find him fit, I'll move your suit, And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
target: If I do find him fit, I'll ask for your favor, And try to get it done the best way I can.

orig: translate old to modern: Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court.
target: The good manners of the court look as silly in the country as country behavior is laughable at the court.

orig: translate old to modern: No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
target: No, villain, but you didn’t work alone.

orig: translate old to modern: How say you, sir?
target: What do you think?

orig: translate old to modern: Open your gates.
target: Open your gates.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you come to bed, my lord?
target: Will you come to bed, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou know’st not gold’s effect.
target: You don’t know what money can buy.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, let us to the banquet.
target: Come on, let’s get to the banquet.

orig: translate old to modern: Father and mother is man and wife; man and wife is one flesh; and so, my mother.
target: Father and mother is man and wife, man and wife is one flesh, and so, my mother.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll slit the villain’s nose that would have sent me to the jail.
target: No, I’ll slit the nose of the villain who would have sent me to jail.

orig: translate old to modern: Thrice within this hour I saw him down, thrice up again and fighting.
target: Three times in an hour I saw him down, and three times up again and fighting.

orig: translate old to modern: But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave And then return lamenting to my love.
target: But first, I’ll dump this fellow in his grave, then return to my love weeping with grief.

orig: translate old to modern: Carry this mad knave to the jail.—Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
target: Take this mad wretch to jail.—Father-in-law Baptista, will you see that he’s available to appear in court?

orig: translate old to modern: He was not three leagues off when I left him.
target: When I left him, he was less than nine miles from here.

orig: translate old to modern: I will forget my nature.
target: I want to forget what I am.

orig: translate old to modern: O royal Caesar!
target: O, royal Caesar!

orig: translate old to modern: The itch of his affection should not then Have nicked his captainship at such a point When half to half the world opposed, he being The merèd question.
target: With half the world opposing the other half, it wasn’t the time for Antony, the pivotal player, to let love distract him.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, poor caitiff!
target: Alas, poor wretch!

target: Did you come from Padua, from Bellario?

orig: translate old to modern: I one, my lord.
target: I am one, my lord.

target: Stand you aside a while; Restrict yourself only in patient way.

orig: translate old to modern: Her mood will needs be pitied.
target: Her mood must be pitied.

orig: translate old to modern: Let’s ha ’t, good soldier.
target: Let’s have one, good soldier.

orig: translate old to modern: Cobweb.
target: Cobweb.

orig: translate old to modern: A good matter, surely.
target: Very impressive.

orig: translate old to modern: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?
target: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unfit for toil and trouble in the world, if not so that our soft qualities and our hearts should agree with our external parts?

orig: translate old to modern: They never meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.
target: Whenever they meet, there’s a little battle.

orig: translate old to modern: For what offence?
target: What did they do wrong?

orig: translate old to modern: Your Honor wins bad humors.
target: Your Honor’s is unhealthy talk.

orig: translate old to modern: I hear their drum.
target: I hear their drums.

orig: translate old to modern: No, sir, no jot.
target: No, sir, not at all.

orig: translate old to modern: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!
target: Sir, such a life with such a wife is unlikely!

orig: translate old to modern: What, my dear Lady Disdain!
target: Look, it’s my dear Lady Disdain!

orig: translate old to modern: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on't.
target: Persist with Desdemona well, and you are sure of it.

orig: translate old to modern: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.
target: Oh, Antonio, I’m sorry I caused you so much trouble.

orig: translate old to modern: Who’s there?
target: Who’s there?

orig: translate old to modern: Is there more toil?
target: Is there more work?

orig: translate old to modern: Will you stay a while?
target: Won’t you wait a minute?

orig: translate old to modern: A deed without a name.
target: A deed without a name.

orig: translate old to modern: Ah, ha!
target: Ah, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: is it true?
target: Is it true, is it true?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, God will send more, if the man will be thankful.
target: Well, eventually God will send him some more hair, if he thanks Him.

orig: translate old to modern: The phrase would be more German to the matter if we could carry a cannon by our sides.
target: The phrase would be more german to the matter if we could carry cannons by our sides.

orig: translate old to modern: Saw you no more?
target: Oh no!

orig: translate old to modern: Look how it steals away!
target: Look how it steals away!

target: Is it true that good King Edward has died?

orig: translate old to modern: Macbeth!
target: Macbeth!

orig: translate old to modern: A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman.
target: It’s just that my wit is very gentlemanly, Margaret, and refuses to hurt a woman.

orig: translate old to modern: No, by this heavenly light!
target: No, by this heavenly light!

orig: translate old to modern: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self.
target: All because of what happened to that brat Rutland?

orig: translate old to modern: This is Signior Antonio.
target: This is Mr. Antonio.

orig: translate old to modern: Read it.
target: Read it.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me but truly—but then speak the truth— Do you not love my sister?
target: Tell me truthfully, do you love my sister?

orig: translate old to modern: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.
target: If the English had any sense, they would run away.

orig: translate old to modern: Fall not a tear, I say.
target: Don’t shed even one tear.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Charmian!
target: Now, Charmian!

orig: translate old to modern: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.
target: At Pembroke, or at Harfordwest in Wales.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll have no bigger.
target: I won’t have one any bigger.

orig: translate old to modern: It was the very day that young Hamlet was born—he that is mad, and sent into England.
target: It was the very day that young Hamlet was born, he that is crazy and sent into England.

orig: translate old to modern: Go armed.
target: Arm yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: The Prince’s fool!
target: The Prince’s fool”!

orig: translate old to modern: Swear.
target: Swear.

orig: translate old to modern: No going then!
target: You didn’t want to go then!

orig: translate old to modern: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?
target: Where is my lord, the duke of Gloucester?

orig: translate old to modern: And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.
target: But don’t kill my sister and her royal sons, be satisfied, dear God, with our blood, which is being spilled unjustly, as you know.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou call me fool, boy?
target: The sweet fool in a fool’s costume—that’s me.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis truly so.
target: It is truly so.

orig: translate old to modern: Think you but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
target: Do you think I would be feeling as triumphant as I am if I didn’t know that our situation was secure?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou'rt mad to say it!
target: You’re crazy to say that!

orig: translate old to modern: she durst not lie Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.
target: she doesn’t dare lie Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.

orig: translate old to modern: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's Should chance— Talk not of standing.
target: Stand together solidly, for fear that some friend of Caesar's Should happen — Don’t talk about standing.—Publius, good cheer!

orig: translate old to modern: Desist, and drink.
target: Give it up and go drink.

orig: translate old to modern: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
target: Who could be out of things to say if he were with the girl he loves?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Hamlet, hear.
target: Now, Hamlet, listen.

orig: translate old to modern: And the rarest that e'er came there.
target: And the rarest person that ever came there.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, here’s grace and a codpiece—that’s a wise man and a fool.
target: A wise man and a fool.

orig: translate old to modern: If that this simple syllogism will serve, so.
target: If this logic works, that’s great.

orig: translate old to modern: He lies not like the living.
target: He doesn’t lie like the living.

orig: translate old to modern: Your constancy Hath left you unattended.
target: Your fortitude Has left you alone.

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing but to show you how a king may go a progress through the guts of a beggar.
target: Nothing but to show you how a king may progress through the guts of a beggar.

orig: translate old to modern: If till the expiration of your month, You will return and sojourn with my sister, Dismissing half your train, come then to me.
target: Get rid of half your knights and go back to spend the rest of your month with my sister.

orig: translate old to modern: Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.
target: I’ll recite something for you, guy.

orig: translate old to modern: O illegitimate construction!
target: Never!

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, even I alone.
target: Yes, I am the one.

orig: translate old to modern: You may to me, and ’tis most meet you should.
target: You may to me, and it is most proper you should.

orig: translate old to modern: See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
target: Don’t greet your bride in these disgraceful clothes.

orig: translate old to modern: Most certain.
target: It’s certain.

orig: translate old to modern: The crowner hath sat on her, and finds it Christian burial.
target: The coroner has decided, and finds it Christian burial.

orig: translate old to modern: He is very busy about it.
target: He is taking care of it as we speak.

orig: translate old to modern: Now gods that we adore, whereof comes this?
target: Dear gods in heaven, what’s the reason for this?

orig: translate old to modern: But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on the sensible Benedick’s head?
target: But when exactly will we see Benedick married?

orig: translate old to modern: It ripens towards it.
target: It’s getting there.

orig: translate old to modern: For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
target: For my own part, I’ll be glad to learn from more capable men.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
target: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.

orig: translate old to modern: What, have you lost your wits?
target: What, have you lost your wits?

orig: translate old to modern: But will you woo this wildcat?
target: Do you really mean to go after this wildcat?

orig: translate old to modern: ROSS: His absence, sir, Lays blame upon his promise.
target: His absence, sir, Means he didn’t keep his promise.

orig: translate old to modern: I pity thy complaining.
target: I pity your situation.

orig: translate old to modern: Base is the slave that pays.
target: Paying debts is for peasants.

orig: translate old to modern: Good night.
target: Good night, Pompey.

orig: translate old to modern: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.
target: You sleep, and I will hold you in my arms.

orig: translate old to modern: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know.
target: I don’t speak to disprove what Brutus spoke, But I’m here to speak what I know.

orig: translate old to modern: There is no more but so.
target: That’s all there is to it.

orig: translate old to modern: A night is but small breath and little pause To answer matters of this consequence.
target: A night isn’t much time for addressing matters of this importance.

orig: translate old to modern: Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly.
target: If Cleopatra hears even a breath of this, she’ll die immediately.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, take it up unto thy master’s use.
target: Go, take it away and let your master make whatever use of it he can.

orig: translate old to modern: We will ourselves provide.
target: We will get ourselves ready.

orig: translate old to modern: To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.
target: You will be an accessory to both crimes.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, the beginning that is dead and buried.
target: Well, we’ve missed the beginning; it’s dead and buried.

orig: translate old to modern: Had he not resembled My father as he slept, I had done't.
target: If the King hadn’t resembled My father as he slept, I would’ve done it.

orig: translate old to modern: Let her know ’t.—   And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.
target: Tell her.

orig: translate old to modern: Be better suited.
target: Change into better clothes.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, is my master yet return'd?
target: Please, is my master returned yet?

orig: translate old to modern: Gratiano, keep the house, And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor, For they succeed on you.
target: Gratiano, keep the house, And seize on the fortunes of the Moor, Because they fall on you.

orig: translate old to modern: I would I had your bond; for I perceive A weak bond holds you; I'll not trust your word.
target: I wish I had your guarantee, because I see that A weak bond holds you; I'll not trust your word.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is more news.
target: Here is more news.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail, Caesar!
target: Hail, Caesar!

orig: translate old to modern: But you are no such man.
target: But you’re no such man.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast railed on thyself.
target: You’ve only insulted yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: It is not lost; but what an if it were?
target: It is not lost; but what if it were?

orig: translate old to modern: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.
target: You can do whatever you want as long as it’s socially appropriate.

orig: translate old to modern: I beseech you.
target: Go ahead..

orig: translate old to modern: Who is here so vile that will not love his country?
target: Who is here so vile that he will not love his country?

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

orig: translate old to modern: Come.
target: Come on.

orig: translate old to modern: Where art thou now?
target: Where are you?

orig: translate old to modern: She was false as water.
target: She was false as water.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you forgot me?
target: Have you forgotten I’m your mother?

orig: translate old to modern: By Janus, I think no.
target: By Janus, I don’t think so.

orig: translate old to modern: If it will not, what remedy?
target: If not, what can you do about it?

orig: translate old to modern: That pure congealed white, high Taurus' snow, Fann'd with the eastern wind, turns to a crow When thou hold'st up thy hand.
target: When you hold up your hand that pure congealed white top, High Taurus' snow, fanned with the eastern wind, Turns to a crow.

orig: translate old to modern: I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
target: I’ll do everything she wants me to do.

orig: translate old to modern: How dost thou, Charles?
target: How are you doing, Charles?

orig: translate old to modern: So.
target: So be it.

orig: translate old to modern: God be wi' you, sir.
target: God be with you, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed.
target: I wouldn’t marry her, even if she were as blessed as paradise.

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways!
target: To hell with all worn-out horses, all crazy masters, and all bad roads.

orig: translate old to modern: By Jove that thunders!
target: By Jove that thunders!

orig: translate old to modern: No doubt, my lord.
target: No doubt, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
target: If you want to cry over my bad luck, I’ll give you my eyes.

orig: translate old to modern: But what of that?
target: But so what?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, pray be covered.
target: No, no, put your hat back on.

orig: translate old to modern: We have beat him to his camp.
target: We’ve driven him all the way back to his camp.

orig: translate old to modern: Wherefore?
target: Why?

orig: translate old to modern: Let th’ Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking.
target: Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor I, my lord.
target: Nor I, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: She soon shall know of us, by some of ours, How honorable and how kindly we Determine for her, for Caesar cannot live To be ungentle.
target: She’ll find out soon enough by one of our messengers how respectfully and kindly we plan to treat her.

orig: translate old to modern: This speech of yours hath moved me, And shall perchance do good.
target: Your words have moved me, and maybe it’ll do some good.

orig: translate old to modern: Go call him hither.
target: Ask him in here.

orig: translate old to modern: Besides, in mercy, The constable desires thee thou wilt mind Thy followers of repentance, that their souls May make a peaceful and a sweet retire From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies Must lie and fester.
target: Moreover, out of mercy, the Constable urges you to remind your men to make their peace with God and repent, so that their souls may depart sweetly and peacefully from these fields where, poor wretches, their bodies will likely fall and fester.

orig: translate old to modern: This ’tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
target: This is to feel the news, not hear it.

orig: translate old to modern: What poor an instrument May do a noble deed!
target: What a poor instrument, that can do such a noble deed!

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.
target: Sir, that’s well said and well thought out.

orig: translate old to modern: If you can look into the seeds of time, And say which grain will grow and which will not, Speak then to me, who neither beg nor fear Your favors nor your hate.
target: If you can look into the future, And say what will happen, and what will not, Then speak to me, who doesn’t beg or is afraid of Your favors or your hateful spells.

orig: translate old to modern: I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury.
target: I’m going to forget my duties to you a little bit and complain about the injuries you’ve caused me.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast braved many men; brave not me.
target: You have bested many things, well don’t try and best me.

orig: translate old to modern: Lorenzo, certain; and my love, indeed; For who love I so much?
target: Lorenzo, to be sure and my love indeed, Because who do love I so much?

orig: translate old to modern: Spout, rain!
target: Let the rain spray!

orig: translate old to modern: It does, my lord.
target: That’s true, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Captain Fluellen.
target: Captain Fluellen!

orig: translate old to modern: I thank your honour.—For my part, my lord, My purpose was not to have seen you here; But meeting with Salerio by the way, He did entreat me, past all saying nay, To come with him along.
target: For my part, my lord, I didn’t intend to see you here; But, meeting with Salanio by the way, He begged me, past all saying no, To come along with him.

orig: translate old to modern: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
target: Yes, that’s all true—but what do you mean by it, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: The weary way hath made you melancholy.
target: The tiring journey seems to have made you gloomy.

orig: translate old to modern: Behold it stained With his most noble blood.
target: Look—his noble blood is still on it.

orig: translate old to modern: You do mistake your business.
target: You’re mistaken.

orig: translate old to modern: Our force by land Hath nobly held.
target: Our land forces have bravely stood firm.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my good lord.
target: Yes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Do not you love me?
target: Do you love me?

orig: translate old to modern: Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace, Yet grace must still look so.
target: Though all things disgustingly filthy would look like grace, Yet grace must still look that way.

orig: translate old to modern: Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.
target: Since she would love both of you, you two would be joined in that love.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s enough.
target: That’s enough.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not have to do with you.
target: I’ll have nothing to do with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Forsooth, a great arithmetician, One Michael Cassio, a Florentine A fellow almost damn'd in a fair wife That never set a squadron in the field, Nor the division of a battle knows More than a spinster; unless the bookish theoric, Where in the toga'd consuls can propose As masterly as he; mere prattle without practice, Is all his soldiership.
target: Truly, a great arithmetician, One Michael Cassio, a Florentine, A fellow almost damned in a having a beautiful wife; That has never led a squadron in the field, And doesn’t know the division of a battle any More than a spinster does, unless the theory books, In which the consuls wearing togas can propose a plan As masterly as he can.

orig: translate old to modern: Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.
target: Lack of trust in my success has done this deed.

orig: translate old to modern: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
target: If I could get my hands on you, I’d make you care.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, down into the boat.
target: Come, this way to the rowboat.

orig: translate old to modern: Heartily farewell.
target: Heartily, farewell.

orig: translate old to modern: Let us seek out some desolate shade and there Weep our sad bosoms empty.
target: Let’s look for some desolate shade and there Cry our hearts out.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool, farewell!
target: You wretched, rash, intruding fool, goodbye!

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.
target: A woman who doesn’t know how to make her own indiscretions look like her husband’s fault is hardly a woman.

orig: translate old to modern: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?
target: Kind Tyrrel, will your news make me happy?

orig: translate old to modern: In my mind's eye, Horatio.
target: In my mind's eye, Horatio.

orig: translate old to modern: Hamlet, this deed, for thine especial safety— Which we do tender as we dearly grieve For that which thou hast done—must send thee hence With fiery quickness.
target: Hamlet, for this deed, for your special safety, Which we do consider as we dearly grieve For what you’ve done, we must send you away With fiery quickness.

orig: translate old to modern: how infinite in faculty!
target: how infinite in faculties!

orig: translate old to modern: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman.
target: A veteran commander and a very kind gentleman.

orig: translate old to modern: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
target: But let me go to my fortune and the chests.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, but to live In the rank sweat of an enseamed bed, Stew'd in corruption, honeying and making love Over the nasty sty!
target: No, but to live In the rotten sweat of an greasy bed, Stewed in corruption, using sweet words and making love Over the nasty pig sty.

orig: translate old to modern: But, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it.
target: but, to my thinking, he was very reluctant to remove his fingers off it.

orig: translate old to modern: A daughter?
target: A daughter?

orig: translate old to modern: So, This is to horse.
target: So, there’s the signal to ride.

orig: translate old to modern: O Spartan dog, More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea!
target: O Spartan dog, More evil than anguish, hunger, or the sea!

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed Sway'd from the point by looking down on Caesar.
target: I shook your hands for that reason; but I was really Distracted from the point by looking down on Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: Hence, Lest that th' infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee.
target: Get out of here, before his bad luck infects you too.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail!
target: Hail!
