target: Fairies, be gone, and stay away.

orig: translate old to modern: What from the cape can you discern at sea?
target: What can you discern at sea from the cape?

orig: translate old to modern: We pray you throw to earth This unprevailing woe, and think of us As of a father; for let the world take note You are the most immediate to our throne, And with no less nobility of love Than that which dearest father bears his son Do I impart toward you.
target: Because, let the whole world know, You are the next in line to our throne, And, I give you my love, with no less nobility Than the love which the dearest father Bears his son.

orig: translate old to modern: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.
target: I am a villain.

orig: translate old to modern: I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes; when they are in great danger, I recover them.
target: I’m indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes; when they’re in great danger, I re-cover them.

orig: translate old to modern: Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.
target: Let’s be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha, ha!
target: Ha, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
target: Take up the sword again, or take me up.

orig: translate old to modern: Is't possible?
target: Is it possible?

orig: translate old to modern: How, in one house, Should many people under two commands Hold amity?
target: How could so many people, under two masters, get along under one roof?

orig: translate old to modern: No, no, he is dead; Go to thy deathbed; He never will come again.
target: No, no, he is dead, Go to your death-bed, He never will come again.

orig: translate old to modern: I am satisfied.
target: I am satisfied.

orig: translate old to modern: Dismiss me.
target: Send me away.

orig: translate old to modern: Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
target: Then you really are insane, if you’re no saner than a fool.

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou a churchman?
target: Oh, you’re a clergyman?

orig: translate old to modern: This I’ll report, dear lady.
target: I’ll tell him all of this, dear lady.

orig: translate old to modern: How far’st thou, soldier?
target: How are you, soldier?

orig: translate old to modern: You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.
target: You’re my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the red tears That visit my sad heart.

orig: translate old to modern: A lioness hath whelped in the streets; And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead; Fierce fiery warriors fight upon the clouds, In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol; The noise of battle hurtled in the air, Horses did neigh and dying men did groan, And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.
target: A lioness has given birth in the streets; And graves have opened up and given up their dead; Fierce fiery warriors fight on the clouds, In ranks and squadrons and right forms of war, Which drizzled blood on the Capitol; The noise of battle screaming into the air, Horses neighed, and dying men groaned;And ghosts shrieked and squealed around the streets.

orig: translate old to modern: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.
target: I’m surprised you enjoy the company of this stupid troublemaker.

orig: translate old to modern: The clerk will ne'er wear hair on's face that had it.
target: No, God's my judge, The clerk will never grow a beard that took it.

orig: translate old to modern: Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be.
target: Lord, we know what we are, but don’t know what we may be.

orig: translate old to modern: Canst thou so daff me?
target: You think you can get rid of me that easily?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost speak masterly.
target: You’re absolutely right.

orig: translate old to modern: So sorrow's heaviness doth heavier grow For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe; Which now in some slight measure it will pay, If for his tender here I make some stay.
target: So sorrow's heaviness does heavier grow Because my sleep has been interrupted.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, sir.
target: Yes, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: You advise me well.
target: You advise me well.

orig: translate old to modern: O me!
target: Oh me!

orig: translate old to modern: Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not smooth, so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will appear in his true likeness.
target: So, possessing neither a voice nor a heart for flattery, I can’t awaken the spirit of love in her so as to make him appear in his true likeness.

orig: translate old to modern: Pox on ’t!
target: That’s it!

orig: translate old to modern: Yonder sure they are coming.
target: Yes, I see them coming.

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou there, truepenny?
target: Are you there, trusty fellow?

orig: translate old to modern: Did you?
target: You did it?

orig: translate old to modern: What should we say, my lord?
target: What should we say, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Who's there?
target: Who's there?

orig: translate old to modern: I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.
target: I have often led you, now you must carry me, my good friends—and take my thanks for everything.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him, I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.
target: If you do bend, and pray, and play up to me for him, I reject you out of my way like a stray dog.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not gamesome; I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.
target: I don’t like games; I lack some part Of that quick spirit that Antony has.

orig: translate old to modern: O, pardon, sir, it doth, and yon grey lines That fret the clouds are messengers of day.
target: O, pardon, sir, it does, and the gray lines over there That adorn the clouds are the messengers of dawn.

orig: translate old to modern: I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate The honour of my child.
target: I have used you, Filth as you are, with human care, and let you live In my own dwelling, until you tried to rape My daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: But how, but how?
target: But how?

orig: translate old to modern: And let him play his music.
target: And let him practice his music.

orig: translate old to modern: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
target: If I’m a wasp, look out for my stinger.

orig: translate old to modern: Aye, sir.
target: Of course, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Whither?
target: Where?

orig: translate old to modern: Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.
target: Prince Dauphin, you’ll stay with me in Rouen.

orig: translate old to modern: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?
target: But did your sister die of love?

orig: translate old to modern: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.
target: I’ll try to persuade him to put on something more appropriate before going to the church, if it’s at all possible.

orig: translate old to modern: Is that any thing now?
target: Is that anything to think about now?

orig: translate old to modern: Use me well.
target: Treat me well.

orig: translate old to modern: I will be satisfied!
target: I will be satisfied or shamed.

orig: translate old to modern: You are deceived.
target: You’re mistaken.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, all’s one for that.
target: Well, it doesn’t matter.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear.—Prithee, tell her but a workaday fortune.
target: Well, if a moist palm isn’t a clear sign of promiscuity, then I can’t scratch my own ear.

orig: translate old to modern: His fault is much, and the good king his master Will check him for ’t.
target: He’s done wrong, and his master the king will punish him for it.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, so I thought.
target: Yes, so I thought.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou bleed’st apace.
target: You’re bleeding a lot.

orig: translate old to modern: Most gracious Duke, To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear.
target: Very gracious duke, Listen with a gracious ear to my request, And let me find a contract in your voice To assist my simpleness.

orig: translate old to modern: And they that are most gallèd with my folly, They most must laugh.
target: And whoever is most irritated by my foolishness has to laugh the hardest.

orig: translate old to modern: Lechery, by this hand; an index and obscure prologue to the history of lust and foul thoughts.
target: I swear it’s a habitual lust, a list and hidden opening to the history of lust and evil thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: White-livered runagate, what doth he there?
target: Lily-livered coward, what’s he doing there?

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, then belike she was old and gentle, and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off and in your straight strossers.
target: Oh, then I guess she was old and gentle, and you rode barelegged, like an Irish yokel.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, that I were a fool!
target: A worthy fool!

orig: translate old to modern: Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
target: It’s strange that you haven’t heard.

orig: translate old to modern: Look, they weep, And I, an ass, am onion-eyed.
target: Look—they’re crying.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, or any show that you'll show him.
target: Yes, or any show that you'll show him.

orig: translate old to modern: What villains have done this?
target: What villains have done this?

orig: translate old to modern: Have at the very eye of that proverb with “A pox of the devil.”  You are the better at proverbs, by how much “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”  You have shot over.
target: I’ll go straight for that proverb with “To hell with the devil.” You are better at proverbs than I am by as much as “A fool shoots quickly and overshoots his mark.” You have overshot.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence, Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
target: I will, as surely as I am a gentleman.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man.
target: But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well, and now he’s become a real man.

orig: translate old to modern: But we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.
target: But I’ll open the curtain and let you see the picture.

orig: translate old to modern: Hamlet, thou art slain; No medicine in the world can do thee good.
target: Hamlet, you are killed, No medicine in the world can save you.

orig: translate old to modern: Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end.
target: I don’t know what you’ve done to upset him, but someone has challenged you to a duel.

orig: translate old to modern: Even here Do we shake hands.
target: Here we’ll shake hands good-bye.

orig: translate old to modern: She shall not.
target: She shall not.

orig: translate old to modern: I am but mad north-north-west.
target: I am but crazy north-north-west.

orig: translate old to modern: And art thou living, Stephano?
target: And are you living, Stephano?

orig: translate old to modern: Even those you were wont to take such delight in, the tragedians of the city.
target: Even those you usually enjoy, the tragedians of the city.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, keep me company but two years more, Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.
target: Well, keep me company for only two more years, and You’ll never know the sound of your own voice.

orig: translate old to modern: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.
target: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard speak, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Save me and hover o'er me with your wings, You heavenly guards!
target: Save me and hover over me with your wings, You heavenly guards!

orig: translate old to modern: My Oberon!
target: My Oberon!

orig: translate old to modern: Till Birnam Wood remove to Dunsinane I cannot taint with fear.
target: I won’t be afraid Until Birnam wood remove to Dunsinane.

orig: translate old to modern: You know not why we came to visit you— Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.
target: You don’t know why we came to visit you— Yes, and so unexpectedly, at night.

orig: translate old to modern: The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide itself.
target: If it were nothing, you wouldn’t need to hide it.

orig: translate old to modern: I am glad thou canst speak no better English, for if thou couldst, thou wouldst find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my farm to buy my crown.
target: If it were, you would find me such an ordinary king that you would think I’d sold my farm to buy my crown.

orig: translate old to modern: So do not I.
target: Yet I wish I could.

orig: translate old to modern: Who?
target: Who?

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we part, sweet girl?
target: Should we part, sweet girl?

orig: translate old to modern: Follow my voice; we'll try no manhood here.
target: Follow my voice; we won’t test your manhood here.

orig: translate old to modern: The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to th’ welkin's cheek, Dashes the fire out.
target: It seems that the sky would pour down stinking, boiling tar, Except that the sea, mounting to the cloud’s cheek, Puts the fire out.

orig: translate old to modern: No, in despite of sense and secrecy, Unpeg the basket on the house's top, Let the birds fly, and like the famous ape, To try conclusions, in the basket creep And break your own neck down.
target: No, in spite of sense and secrecy, Don’t open the basket on the roof, Let the birds fly, and, like the famous ape To test conclusions, don’t creep into the basket And break your own neck.

orig: translate old to modern: Who intercepts my expedition?
target: Who’s blocking the way?

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
target: Nothing that interests me, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: She's framed as fruitful As the free elements.
target: She's been made as fruitful As the free elements.

orig: translate old to modern: Go off, I discard you.
target: Go away.

orig: translate old to modern: Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil Would not infect his reason?
target: Who is so firm, so constant, that this noisy disturbance Would not infect his sanity?

orig: translate old to modern: O, yet I do repent me of my fury, That I did kill them.
target: O, I’m sorry I was so angry That I did kill them.

orig: translate old to modern: I would your duty were as foolish too.
target: I wish your loyalty were as foolish.

orig: translate old to modern: As a friend or an enemy?
target: As a friend or an enemy?

orig: translate old to modern: How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief That was my wife's?
target: Cassio, how did you come by that handkerchief That was my wife's?

orig: translate old to modern: Is this true, Nerissa?
target: Is this true, Nerissa?

orig: translate old to modern: I will to Venice.
target: I’m off to Venice.

orig: translate old to modern: What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
target: What news can you tell me in this fast-moving, unsteady state of ours?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis true.
target: It’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, th' athversary was have possession of the pridge, but he is enforced to retire, and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge.
target: Indeed, the enemy nearly took the bridge, but he was forced to retreat, and the duke of Exeter holds the bridge.

orig: translate old to modern: Besides—I ha' not since put up my sword— Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glazed upon me and went surly by Without annoying me: and there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women Transformed with their fear, who swore they saw Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
target: Besides,—I haven’t used my sword since— I met a lion, in front of the Capitol, Who glared at me, and angrily passed me by, Without attacking me, and there were a hundred ghastly Women gathered in a heap, Transformed by their fear; who swore they saw Men, all on fire, walking up and down the streets.

orig: translate old to modern: The duke’s to blame in this.
target: It’s wrong for the duke to do this.

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, Demetrius!
target: Shame on you, Demetrius!

orig: translate old to modern: Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife, If it would please him come and marry her!”   Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.
target: So now everyone will point at me and say, “Look, there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio—if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing!”

orig: translate old to modern: Your worship was wont to tell me, I could do nothing without bidding.
target: You, sir, always told me I couldn’t do anything without bidding.

orig: translate old to modern: The moon shines bright:—in such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees, And they did make no noise,—in such a night, Troilus, methinks, mounted the Trojan walls, And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents, Where Cressid lay that night.
target: The moon shines bright: in such a night as this, When the sweet wind gently kissed the trees, And they made no noise, in such a night, Troilus I think climbed the walls of Troy, And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents, Where Cressida lay that night.

orig: translate old to modern: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
target: Have you heard of me, most noble Empress?

orig: translate old to modern: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
target: O young and noble Cato, are you down?

orig: translate old to modern: What, look you pale?
target: What, do you look pale?

orig: translate old to modern: I was a fine fool to take it.
target: I was a fine fool to take it.

orig: translate old to modern: I have done the state some service, and they know't.
target: I have done the state some service, and they know it.

orig: translate old to modern: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
target: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this.

orig: translate old to modern: At mine own house, good lady.
target: At mine own house, good lady.

orig: translate old to modern: My love is thine to teach.
target: I am at your service.

orig: translate old to modern: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And started when he looked upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.
target: Three times today my horse stumbled and started when he looked in the direction of the Tower, as if he hated to carry me to this slaughterhouse.

orig: translate old to modern: I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
target: I didn’t come, friends, to steal away your hearts.

orig: translate old to modern: I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus.
target: I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus.

orig: translate old to modern: Is he of God’s making?
target: Did God make him?

orig: translate old to modern: By this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant, monster, or my standard.
target: You shall be my lieutenant, monster, or my main officer.

orig: translate old to modern: Come apace, good Audrey.
target: Come on, sweet Audrey.

orig: translate old to modern: Bow, stubborn knees; and heart with strings of steel, Be soft as sinews of the new-born babe!
target: Bow, stubborn knees, and, heart, with strings of steel, Be soft as the muscles of the newborn baby!

orig: translate old to modern: You wrong me, Signior Gremio.
target: Please, Signior Gremio.

orig: translate old to modern: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?
target: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, or anything?

orig: translate old to modern: I must with haste from hence.
target: I have to leave right away.

orig: translate old to modern: O, never Shall sun that morrow see!
target: O, the sun shall never See that tomorrow!

orig: translate old to modern: He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
target: Benedick’s heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

orig: translate old to modern: Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die, meantime Laugh at his challenge.
target: Let the old ruffian discover that I have many other ways to die, and in the meantime, we’ll laugh at his challenge.

orig: translate old to modern: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
target: Are Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

orig: translate old to modern: Good duke, receive thy daughter.
target: Good duke, come receive your daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: O, come in, Emilia.
target: O, come in, Emilia.

orig: translate old to modern: Let copulation thrive, for Gloucester’s bastard son Was kinder to his father than my daughters got ’tween the lawful sheets.
target: Let’s have more sex in the world, since Gloucester’s bastard son was kinder to him than my daughters, conceived in lawful wedlock, have been to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Good my lord, tell it.
target: My good lord, tell it.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
target: Alas, why do you chew your nether lip so?

orig: translate old to modern: It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
target: It has to be of mild, tender, and delicate climate.

orig: translate old to modern: You must leave this.
target: You must stop this.

orig: translate old to modern: All's one.
target: Makes no difference.

orig: translate old to modern: If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in all things.
target: If you look closely at Alexander’s life, Harry of Monmouth’s stands up fairly well by comparison—for there are analogies in everything.

orig: translate old to modern: For the law of writ and the liberty, these are the only men.
target: For the law of writ and the liberty, these are the only men.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha!
target: Ha!

orig: translate old to modern: O God, your only jig-maker!
target: O, your only dancer!

orig: translate old to modern: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
target: Oh Margaret, Margaret, your heavy curse has now landed on poor Hastings’s miserable head!

orig: translate old to modern: I do not think't.
target: I don’t think so.

orig: translate old to modern: Tonight I take my leave.
target: Now I have to leave.

orig: translate old to modern: Abide within.
target: Stay within.

orig: translate old to modern: O heavy burden!
target: O heavy burden!

orig: translate old to modern: Stay!
target: Stay!

orig: translate old to modern: peace, this piece of toasted cheese will do ’t.
target: piece of cheese will get him.—I challenge you to a match.

orig: translate old to modern: We have sworn, my lord, already.
target: We have sworn, my lord, already.

orig: translate old to modern: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?
target: Young budding virgin, fair and pure and sweet, where are you off to?

orig: translate old to modern: Give me up the truth.
target: Tell me the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
target: I bother you too much, but you’re willing.

orig: translate old to modern: here's a small trifle of wives: alas, fifteen wives is nothing; aleven widows and nine maids, is a simple coming-in for one man: and then, to 'scape drowning thrice; and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a feather bed; here are simple 'scapes!
target: And then to escape drowning three times, and to be in fear for my life with the edge of a feather bed; here are simple escapes.

orig: translate old to modern: But where tomorrow?
target: But where will I lie tomorrow?

orig: translate old to modern: He's gone, but his wife's kill'd.
target: He's gone, but his wife's killed.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome hither.
target: You’re welcome here.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it?
target: What’s that?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, then, I'll set those to you that can speak.
target: No, then, I’ll send those to you who can speak.

orig: translate old to modern: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I’ll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
target: I ordered that the sleeves be cut out and sewed up again, and I’ll prove it in combat even if your little finger is armed with your thimble.

orig: translate old to modern: He knows not what he says, and vain it is That we present us to him.
target: He doesn’t know what he’s saying.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.
target: I’ll have my head cut from my shoulders before I’ll see the crown so misplaced.

orig: translate old to modern: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things, That now give evidence against my soul, For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me.— O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!
target: I did them for Edward’s sake—and look how he rewards me.—Oh God, if my prayers don’t satisfy you, and you have to avenge the wrongs I’ve done, at least punish me alone!

orig: translate old to modern: How now, friend Eros!
target: How goes it, friend Eros?

orig: translate old to modern: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
target: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning”—please, tell me what you meant by that.

orig: translate old to modern: The man that hath no music in himself, Nor is not mov'd with concord of sweet sounds, Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils; The motions of his spirit are dull as night, And his affections dark as Erebus: Let no such man be trusted.—Mark the music.
target: The man that has no music in him, Or is not moved by harmony of sweet sounds, Is fit for treasons, plots, and stealing; The movement of his spirit is as dull as night, And his affections are as dark as the place between Earth and hell.

orig: translate old to modern: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
target: here's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

orig: translate old to modern: Let them guard the door.
target: Let them guard the door.

orig: translate old to modern: He is enamored on Hero.
target: He is in love with Hero.

orig: translate old to modern: Hence.
target: Away!

orig: translate old to modern: All's well now, sweeting; come away to bed.
target: All's well now, sweetheart; come away to bed.

orig: translate old to modern: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.
target: Let’s have explicit contracts drawn up to ensure that both sides keep their promises.

orig: translate old to modern: He saves my labor by his own approach.
target: He saved me the trouble: here he comes.

orig: translate old to modern: Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.
target: Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

orig: translate old to modern: Go carry them, and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.
target: Go carry them, and smear The sleepy guards with blood.

orig: translate old to modern: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!
target: Two thousand ducats a year from his land!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, you would beg, Were you in my distress.
target: Yes, you would beg, if you were in my position.

orig: translate old to modern: For the love o' God, peace!
target: For God’s sake, shut up!

orig: translate old to modern: Thus I let you go And give you to the gods.
target: And thus I let you go and give you to the gods.

orig: translate old to modern: No, faith, my lord.
target: No, faith, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Advise the duke where you are going, to a most festinate preparation.
target: Tell the Duke of Albany to prepare for war immediately.

orig: translate old to modern: Learn it, learn it, marquess.
target: Take it to heart, Dorset.

orig: translate old to modern: The duke of Exeter has very gallantly maintained the pridge.
target: The duke of Exeter has held the bridge very gallantly.

orig: translate old to modern: Lend me a looking-glass.
target: Let me borrow a mirror.

orig: translate old to modern: Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily.
target: Look out for him in the corner of the orchard as if you were a sheriff’s deputy.

orig: translate old to modern: I will the banner from a trumpet take And use it for my haste.
target: I’ll take the banner from a trumpeter and use that.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
target: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you getting on with my daughter?

orig: translate old to modern: Juno sings her blessings upon you.
target: Juno sings her blessings on you.

orig: translate old to modern: World, world, O world!
target: Oh, life is full of surprises!

orig: translate old to modern: What, ho, Brabantio!
target: what, ho, Brabantio!

orig: translate old to modern: The Queen his mother Lives almost by his looks; and for myself— My virtue or my plague, be it either which— She's so conjunctive to my life and soul That, as the star moves not but in his sphere, I could not but by her.
target: The queen his mother Lives almost by his looks, and for myself, Whether it’s my virtue or my plague, She's so necessary to my life and soul, That, as the star moves only in his orbit, I couldn’t do anything without her say-so.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis monstrous.
target: It is monstrous.

orig: translate old to modern: They swore you did.
target: They swore you did.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, madam.
target: Yes, ma'am.

orig: translate old to modern: Who's there?
target: Who's there?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there’s gold.
target: That’s a nice hand you dealt me.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick.
target: All right Ursula, as Beatrice arrives, we’ll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick.

orig: translate old to modern: One ever near thee.
target: Someone who was always near you.

orig: translate old to modern: At sea, I think.
target: I think it was at sea.

orig: translate old to modern: Whiles I in this affair do thee employ, I'll to my queen, and beg her Indian boy; And then I will her charmed eye release From monster's view, and all things shall be peace.
target: While I use you to solve this affair, I'll go to my queen, and beg the Indian boy from her; And then I will release her charmed eye So that she will see the monster, and all things shall be at peace.

orig: translate old to modern: Two months since Here was a gentleman of Normandy— I have seen myself, and served against, the French, And they can well on horseback; but this gallant Had witchcraft in't.
target: Two months ago, There was a gentleman from Normandy here, I’ve seen myself, and served against the French, And they can do well on horseback, but this gallant Had witchcraft in it.

orig: translate old to modern: I have done ill, Of which I do accuse myself so sorely That I will joy no more.
target: I’ve done a bad thing, for which I will blame myself so much that I’ll never be happy again.

orig: translate old to modern: And I’ll sleep.
target: And I’m going to sleep.

orig: translate old to modern: There's fennel for you, and columbines.
target: There's fennel for you, and columbines.

orig: translate old to modern: Edgar I nothing am.
target: As Edgar, I’m nothing at all.

orig: translate old to modern: Let’s see these pockets.
target: Let’s look in his pockets.

orig: translate old to modern: I will hear further reason for this.
target: I will hear further reason for this.

orig: translate old to modern: The  I thank you.
target: Thank you.

orig: translate old to modern: What, now?
target: What, now?

orig: translate old to modern: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
target: My dear Miss Chat-her-up, I look forward to getting to know you better.

orig: translate old to modern: At home, my lord.
target: At home, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: The glove which I have given him for a favor May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear.
target: The glove which I have given him to wear may possibly win him a box on the ear.

orig: translate old to modern: Would all were well—but that will never be.
target: I wish I could believe you that all was well!

orig: translate old to modern: You more invest it!
target: How, in stripping it bare, You invest more in it!

orig: translate old to modern: I will be flesh and blood, For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.
target: I intend to be flesh and blood, not airy philosophy, for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently, even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune.

orig: translate old to modern: Know’st thou Gower?
target: Do you know Captain Gower?

orig: translate old to modern: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his.
target: If there is anyone in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his love.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll tell the news.
target: I'll tell the news.

orig: translate old to modern: The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
target: There’s a nice reason why the constellation Pleiades has only seven stars in it.

orig: translate old to modern: If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
target: I don’t care if all the devils in hell crammed together to possess him, I still want to speak to him.

orig: translate old to modern: Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars.
target: Gower is a good captain, and is well versed and well read in the wars.

orig: translate old to modern: I care not for good life.
target: I’m not interested in being good.

orig: translate old to modern: Gave it a judge's clerk!—no, God's my judge!
target: Gave it a judge's clerk!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, a horse.
target: Well, the difference of a horse!

orig: translate old to modern: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think’st his very action speaks In every power that moves.
target: Observe how Antony takes his defeat and how his attitude influences his actions.

orig: translate old to modern: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.
target: I’m as crazy as he is, if sad craziness and happy craziness are equivalent.

orig: translate old to modern: I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after.
target: Just looking at him gives me heartburn.

orig: translate old to modern: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father; The which will I, not all so much for love As for another secret close intent By marrying her which I must reach unto.
target: So that’s what I’ll do, not because I love her but because I’ll get something out of it.

orig: translate old to modern: Is it possible?
target: Is it possible?

orig: translate old to modern: Thy spirit walks abroad, and turns our swords In our own proper entrails.
target: Your spirit walks abroad, and turns our swords Into our own guts.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up My mortified spirit.
target: You, like an exorcist, have brought my dead Spirit back to life.

orig: translate old to modern: But she is none.
target: But she is no virgin.

orig: translate old to modern: What, you egg!
target: What, you egg!

orig: translate old to modern: How doth the lady?
target: How is she?

orig: translate old to modern: I hate it as an unfilled can.
target: I hate your logic as much as I hate an empty drinking cup.

orig: translate old to modern: No, sir, the worse.
target: No, sir, worse off.

orig: translate old to modern: thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my phill-horse has on his tail.
target: You have got more hair on your chin than Dobbin my thrill-horse has on his tail.

orig: translate old to modern: Under what captain serve you?
target: What captain do you serve?

orig: translate old to modern: Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which, if thou hast considered, let us know If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.
target: It’s proper that we speak first, which is why we sent our proposals ahead of us for your consideration.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come; Lend me a light.
target: Come, come; Lend me a light.

orig: translate old to modern: I confess the cape.
target: I admit the cape.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I say no.
target: Well, I disagree.

orig: translate old to modern: So hangs and lolls and weeps upon me; so hales and pulls me.
target: So hangs, and lolls, and weeps on me; so hales and pulls me.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus it must be.
target: It must go like this.

orig: translate old to modern: I will, my lord.
target: I will, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: If 'twere no other— 'Tis but so, I warrant.
target: If it were any other… It’s only that, I guarantee it.

orig: translate old to modern: Worse and worse.
target: Worse and worse!

orig: translate old to modern: If it had been painful, I would not have come.
target: If the job had been painful, I would not have come.

orig: translate old to modern: Know’st thou this country?
target: Don’t give up yet.

orig: translate old to modern: I should have given ’t you today morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.
target: I would’ve given it to you this morning, but a madman’s letters aren’t Gospel, so it doesn’t matter much if I’m a bit late.

orig: translate old to modern: Heaven and earth!
target: Oh, God!

orig: translate old to modern: I wish your horses swift and sure of foot, And so I do commend you to their backs.
target: I wish your horses are swift and sure of foot, And so go on for your ride.

orig: translate old to modern: And when he saw my best alarumed spirits, Bold in the quarrel’s right, roused to the encounter, Or whether ghasted by the noise I made, Full suddenly he fled.
target: Bolstered by righteousness, I prepared to fight, and when he saw my excitement—or perhaps because my shouting scared him—he ran away suddenly.

orig: translate old to modern: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here, Which never labour'd in their minds till now; And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories With this same play against your nuptial.
target: Hard working men that work here in Athens, Who never worked in their minds until now, And now they have toiled their bad memories To do this play in honor of your wedding.

orig: translate old to modern: I will construe to them whence you come.
target: I’ll tell them where you come from, though I don’t know who you are or what you want.

orig: translate old to modern: Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship.
target: You’ve shut me up in a dark room and given your drunken cousin authority over me, but I’m as sane as you are.

orig: translate old to modern: One way I like this well.
target: Did he lose his other eye?

orig: translate old to modern: He hath been a courtier, he swears.
target: He swears he used to be a courtier.

orig: translate old to modern: The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, And gentlemen of blood and quality.
target: The rest of the dead are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, and gentlemen of birth and rank.

orig: translate old to modern: Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me.
target: Ratcliffe, around midnight come to my tent and help me put on my armor.

orig: translate old to modern: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart.
target: I never heard so loud a voice issue from such an empty heart.

orig: translate old to modern: Masters, you are all welcome.
target: Masters, you are all welcome.

orig: translate old to modern: let their beds Be made as soft as yours, and let their palates Be season'd with such viands?
target: Let their beds Be made as soft as yours, and let their palates Be seasoned with such rich meats?

orig: translate old to modern: There's another.
target: There's another.

orig: translate old to modern: Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honor and her love Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
target: How can I describe you that will make you appeal to the young woman and will also agree with God, the law, my honor, and her feelings?

orig: translate old to modern: The Queen Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend Or take his life there.
target: I’ll give the Queen a hearing and grant her requests if she either throws her dishonored friend out of Egypt or kills him.

orig: translate old to modern: O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!
target: I have broken his command not to say so.

orig: translate old to modern: But God above Deal between thee and me!
target: Only God above Deal between you and me!

orig: translate old to modern: Give o'er the play.
target: Stop the play.

orig: translate old to modern: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
target: And I would die a thousand deaths cheerfully, if it made your life easier.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray thee.
target: Speak, my fair one, and speak fairly, I beg you.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweet masters, be patient.
target: Gentlemen, calm down.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll none of it.
target: I won’t take it.

orig: translate old to modern: The meantime, lady, I’ll raise the preparation of a war Shall stain your brother.
target: In the meantime, I’ll raise an army that will surpass his.

orig: translate old to modern: The little dogs and all, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—see, they bark at me.
target: Look at the three little dogs, Tray, Blanch, and Sweetheart—all barking at me.

orig: translate old to modern: If we should fail?
target: If we should fail?

orig: translate old to modern: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus.
target: It remains like this, and the remainder like this.

orig: translate old to modern: If they deny to come, Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
target: If they refuse to come, get physical—use a whip if you have to, but get them out here to their husbands.

orig: translate old to modern: I never hurt you.
target: I never hurt you.

orig: translate old to modern: He is the general challenger.
target: He is the general challenger.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet have I left a daughter.
target: You’re not really my daughter, but I still have one daughter left.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”
target: Please smile whenever you’re near me, my dearest darling.”

orig: translate old to modern: Fare you well, sir.
target: Goodbye, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus have I, wall, my part discharged so; And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.
target: So I, wall, have discharged my part; And, being done, Wall goes away like this.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
target: My lord, I think I saw him last night.

orig: translate old to modern: I will pour some in [Caliban drinks] thy other mouth.
target: I will pour some in your other mouth.

orig: translate old to modern: Good.
target: Good.

orig: translate old to modern: And that you would have me to do?
target: And you would have me do that?

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, do not turn me about; my stomach is not constant.
target: Please, don’t turn me around so much: my stomach is upset.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my good lord.
target: No, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: And I am your Rosalind.
target: And I am your Rosalind.

orig: translate old to modern: I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream.
target: I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream.

orig: translate old to modern: yea, a Daniel!
target: Yes, a prophet!

orig: translate old to modern: I have done my duty.
target: I’ve only done my duty.

orig: translate old to modern: Demetrius, I'll avouch it to his head, Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena, And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes, Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry, Upon this spotted and inconstant man.
target: Demetrius, I'll swear it on his head, Pursued Nedar's daughter, Helena, the same way, And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, loves, Devoutly loves, loves to the point of divine worship, This spotted and inconstant man.

orig: translate old to modern: O, be thou damn'd, inexecrable dog!
target: Oh, damn you, stubborn dog!

orig: translate old to modern: Vex not his ghost.
target: Don’t disturb his soul.

orig: translate old to modern: In such a night as this!
target: On a night like this!

orig: translate old to modern: Your father was ever virtuous; and holy men at their death have good inspirations; therefore, the lottery that he hath devised in these three chests, of gold, silver, and lead, (whereof who chooses his meaning chooses you,) will, no doubt, never be chosen by any rightly, but one who you shall rightly love.
target: Your father was always a holy man, and holy men have good ideas when they die; so the lottery that he has thought up in these three chests, made of gold, of silver, and of lead, by means of which whoever chooses the right chest chooses you, will, no doubt, never be chosen by the right man except the one you shall rightly love.

orig: translate old to modern: Go therefore, tell thy master: here I am.
target: Anyway, go tell your master I am here.

orig: translate old to modern: What, are you mad?
target: What, are you crazy?

orig: translate old to modern: What is the matter?
target: What is the matter?

orig: translate old to modern: What, removed?
target: what, gone?

orig: translate old to modern: We have lost best half of our affair.
target: We have lost best half of our attack.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
target: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: God be with my old master.
target: God bless my old master.

orig: translate old to modern: O, let me make the period to my curse!
target: Let me finish my curse.

orig: translate old to modern: Thieves!
target: Thieves!

orig: translate old to modern: Who is it in the press that calls on me?
target: Who’s calling for me?

orig: translate old to modern: I speak not yet of proof.
target: I don’t speak yet of proof.

orig: translate old to modern: I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable.
target: I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument; I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.
target: If you nod, you’ll break your harp; I'll take it from you, and, good boy, good night.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, infidel, I have thee on the hip.
target: Now, infidel, I have you at a disadvantage.

orig: translate old to modern: But break, my heart, for I must hold my tongue!
target: But, break my heart, for I must be silent!

orig: translate old to modern: I'll observe his looks; I'll tent him to the quick.
target: I’ll observe his looks, I’ll watch his every move.

orig: translate old to modern: Let us haste to hear it, And call the noblest to the audience.
target: Let us hurry to hear it, And call the noblest to hear it too.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, you're drunk.
target: Come on, come on, you're drunk.

orig: translate old to modern: These injuries the king now bears will be revenged home.
target: The humiliation that the king is suffering now will be revenged thoroughly.

orig: translate old to modern: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.
target: My pretty children, both of you misunderstand me.

orig: translate old to modern: Something sure of state, Either from Venice or some unhatch'd practice Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him, Hath puddled his clear spirit; and in such cases Men's natures wrangle with inferior things, Though great ones are their object.
target: Surely it’s some matter of state, Either from Venice or some minor problem Shown to him here in Cyprus, That has muddied his clear spirit, and in such cases Men's natures fight with inferior things, Although their object is great ones.

orig: translate old to modern: I shall fall.
target: I shall faint.

orig: translate old to modern: Traverse, go, provide thy money.
target: Go ahead; go; provide your money.

orig: translate old to modern: Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.
target: Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die, for she says she’ll die if he doesn’t love her, and that she’ll die before she tells him, and she’ll die if he woos her and she’s made to hold back even one of her usual insults.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, let's have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing; I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.
target: Please, let's have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing; I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.

orig: translate old to modern: Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects.
target: Your Grace does me as great an honor as could be wished by any of his subjects.

orig: translate old to modern: Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.
target: Please, my lady, just confirm that you’re the lady of the house so I can get on with my speech.

orig: translate old to modern: You are not wood, you are not stones, but men; And, being men, hearing the will of Caesar, It will inflame you, it will make you mad.
target: You aren’t wood, you aren’t stones, you are men; And, being men, hearing the will of Caesar, It will inflame you; it will make you crazy.

orig: translate old to modern: How is it that the clouds still hang on you?
target: How is it that the clouds still hang on you?

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, do but think You stand upon the rivage and behold A city on th' inconstant billows dancing, For so appears this fleet majestical Holding due course to Harfleur.
target: Pretend that you’re standing on the shore, watching a city dance on the shifting waves, and you’ll have an idea of the look of this majestic fleet as it holds a straight course for Harfleur.

orig: translate old to modern: O Iras, Charmian!
target: Oh, Iras, Charmian!

orig: translate old to modern: The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.
target: The devil inside him is rough, but we can’t treat it roughly.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, poor country, Almost afraid to know itself!
target: Alas, poor country, Almost afraid to know itself!

orig: translate old to modern: What was thy cause?
target: What are you accused of?

orig: translate old to modern: Poor man!
target: Poor man!

orig: translate old to modern: O noble English, that could entertain With half their forces the full pride of France And let another half stand laughing by, All out of work and cold for action!
target: O noble English, who could take on the entire French army with only half their forces, leaving the other half to stand by, idle and laughing.

orig: translate old to modern: In most profound earnest, and, I’ll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice.
target: Very serious, and I’m sure it’s because of Beatrice.

orig: translate old to modern: She is a royal princess.
target: She has royal blood.

orig: translate old to modern: The goodness of the night upon you, friends!
target: The goodness of the night on you, friends!

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
target: Did it really work?

orig: translate old to modern: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
target: Oh my God, what a terrible world this is!

orig: translate old to modern: God be wi' you.
target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, he’s returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
target: Oh, yes, Benedick has returned and is as cheerful as ever.

orig: translate old to modern: What say you?
target: What did you say?

orig: translate old to modern: Come, gentlemen, Let us consult upon tomorrow’s business Into my tent.
target: Come, gentlemen, let’s discuss tomorrow’s action in my tent.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, here, sir!
target: Here, here, sir!

orig: translate old to modern: It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
target: It must be something I did accidentally.

orig: translate old to modern: Who can blot that name With any just reproach?
target: Who can stain that name with a just accusation?

orig: translate old to modern: Wherefore is that?
target: What are you doing with a sword?

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, Iago; we must to the watch.
target: Welcome, Iago; we must go to the guard.

orig: translate old to modern: You that choose not by the view, Chance as fair, and choose as true!
target: You that choose not by looks, Gamble as fair and choose as true!

orig: translate old to modern: Motley’s the only wear.
target: Motley is the only thing to wear.

orig: translate old to modern: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus’ car.
target: He deserves it, even if it were covered with jewels like holy

orig: translate old to modern: Go, sirrah, seek him.
target: Go look for him.

orig: translate old to modern: What says the golden chest?
target: What says the golden chest?

orig: translate old to modern: mutinies, in countries discord, in palaces treason, and the bond cracked ’twixt son and father.
target: break out, civil war erupts, kings are betrayed, and the bond between father and son snaps.

orig: translate old to modern: When they next wake, all this derision Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision; And back to Athens shall the lovers wend, With league whose date till death shall never end.
target: When they next wake up, all this conflict Shall seem to be a dream and a worthless vision; And back to Athens the lovers shall go With happiness and agreement that will never end.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, what's the matter?
target: Why, what's the matter?

orig: translate old to modern: The sun doth gild our armor.
target: The sun glints off our armor.

orig: translate old to modern: But let me conjure you by the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a better proposer could charge you withal, be even and direct with me, whether you were sent for or no.
target: But let me beg you, by the rights of our fellowship, by the harmony of our youth, by the obligation of our ever preserved love, and by anything else that could charge you to be even and direct with me, were you were sent for or not?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I have done.
target: No, I’ve had my say.

orig: translate old to modern: let me see.
target: Let me think.

orig: translate old to modern: Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so—” Am I made?
target: Go ahead.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, what else?
target: Yes, certainly.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay here.
target: Stay here.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, lady.
target: Welcome, lady.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes Sir Oliver.—Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met.
target: Here comes Sir Oliver.

orig: translate old to modern: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition.
target: I think it is the weakness of my eyes That sees this monstrous ghost.

orig: translate old to modern: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern hold their course for England.
target: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are still going to England.

orig: translate old to modern: His leg is but so-so—and yet ’tis well.
target: His legs aren’t great, but they’re alright.

orig: translate old to modern: But down.
target: Stay down, heart.

orig: translate old to modern: He’s fortified against any denial.
target: He’s got an answer for everything.

orig: translate old to modern: I never gave him any.
target: I never offended him at all.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, if this suit lay in Bianca's power, How quickly should you speed!
target: Now, if this promise was in Bianca's power, How quickly you would you succeed!

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver?
target: Should we sing a round to wake up the night owl?

orig: translate old to modern: Where’s my cousin Toby?
target: Where’s my cousin Toby?

orig: translate old to modern: Hem them away.
target: Cough them up.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
target: Come, come, you weak, ungovernable worms!

orig: translate old to modern: Tears seven times salt, Burn out the sense and virtue of mine eye!
target: Tears with seven times the Salt, burn out the sight and truth of my eyes!

orig: translate old to modern: I pull in resolution and begin To doubt the equivocation of the fiend That lies like truth.

orig: translate old to modern: I saw Bassanio and Antonio part: Bassanio told him, he would make some speed Of his return; he answer'd—Do not so, Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio, But stay the very riping of the time; And for the Jew's bond, which he hath of me, Let it not enter in your mind of love: Be merry; and employ your chiefest thoughts To courtship, and such fair ostents of love, As shall conveniently become you there: And even there, his eye being big with tears, Turning his face, he put his hand behind him, And, with affection wondrous sensible, He wrung Bassanio's hand, and so they parted.
target: He answered 'Don’t hurry back; Don’t be careless with business for my sake, Bassanio, But wait until your plans are realized; And for the Jew's promise to pay which he has from me, Don’t let it enter your mind, thinking about love: Be happy, and use your main thoughts For courtship, and such beautiful shows of love That may agree with you there.” And even there, his eyes being big with tears, Turning his face away, he put his hands behind him, And with affection that was amazingly easy to feel, He shook and shook Bassanio's hand, and they parted like that.
