orig: translate old to modern: Let me find him, fortune!
target: Let me find him, fortune!

orig: translate old to modern: To business that we love we rise betimes And go to ’t with delight.
target: When we love our job we get up early and go to it joyfully.

orig: translate old to modern: Only I yield to die.
target: But I yield to die.

orig: translate old to modern: I may sit in a corner and cry, “Heigh-ho for a husband!” Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
target: I should sit in the corner and sing that song, “Heigh-Ho for a Husband!” Lady Beatrice, I’ll get you a husband.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, the dust Should have ascended to the roof of heaven, Raised by your populous troops.
target: The dust from your attending troops should have risen to heaven.

orig: translate old to modern: I do.
target: I do.

orig: translate old to modern: You’re welcome hither.
target: Nice to see you.

orig: translate old to modern: He that thou knowest thine, Hamlet.
target: He that you knows you, HAMLET.

orig: translate old to modern: Disloyal?
target: Unfaithful?

orig: translate old to modern: Calls my lord?
target: Calls my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: No shame but mine.
target: The humiliation is all mine.

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing but death shall stay me.
target: Nothing but death shall stop me.

orig: translate old to modern: sola, sola!
target: Hey, hey!

orig: translate old to modern: What is Thisbe?
target: What is Thisbe?

orig: translate old to modern: They have not been commanded, mighty king.
target: They haven’t been commanded to go to the west, mighty king.

orig: translate old to modern: Our day is gone; Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!
target: Our day is gone; Come clouds, dews, and dangers; our deeds are done!

orig: translate old to modern: If his fitness speaks, mine is ready; now or when- soever, provided I be so able as now.
target: If he is ready now, I am too, now or whenever, provided that I am so able as I am now.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak, speak!
target: Speak, speak!

orig: translate old to modern: Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you my queen.
target: With that I kiss your hand and call you my queen.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, rare for Antony!
target: How excellent for Antony!

orig: translate old to modern: Once more, Cesario, Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.
target: Cesario, go visit that cruel Olivia one more time.

orig: translate old to modern: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man’s apparel?
target: You’d better get me  But does he know that I’m here in the forest and dressed in men’s clothing?

orig: translate old to modern: Ourselves we do not owe.
target: We human beings don’t control our own destinies.

orig: translate old to modern: It is no hidden virtue in him.
target: His virtue is not hidden.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
target: Yes, sir, and I’ll leave when you ask me to.

orig: translate old to modern: He brushes his hat o' mornings.
target: He brushes his hat in the mornings.

orig: translate old to modern: O, the kindest Kate!
target: Darling Kate!

orig: translate old to modern: Most heathenish and most gross!
target: Very heathenish and very gross!

orig: translate old to modern: But, if you knew to whom you show this honour, How true a gentleman you send relief, How dear a lover of my lord your husband, I know you would be prouder of the work, Than customary bounty can enforce you.
target: But if you knew to whom you give this friendship, How true a gentleman you send in relief, How dear a friend of my lord is your husband, I know you show more pride in the work Than accustomed behavior can make you show.

orig: translate old to modern: He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour.
target: He’s been over there practicing how to act for the past half hour.

orig: translate old to modern: A whoreson, mad fellow's it was.
target: A bastard, crazy fellow's it was.

orig: translate old to modern: To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar
target: I myself, who am more indebted to you than anyone, have brought you this young scholar

orig: translate old to modern: I tell thee, churlish priest, A ministering angel shall my sister be When thou liest howling.
target: I tell you, churlish priest, My sister shall be a ministering angel When you lie howling.

orig: translate old to modern: If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
target: If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear what I have to say, I shall beg him to take care of himself.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis paltry to be Caesar.
target: It’s pathetic to be Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not so well as I should be, but I’ll ne’er out.
target: I don’t feel so well, but I won’t stop.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the duke and the duchess on his wedding-day at night.
target: Here is the list of every man's name, who are thought to be the best in all Athens, to play in our play before the duke and duchess at night on their wedding-day.

orig: translate old to modern: An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem to signify.
target: If you will please break this up, it will become clear.

orig: translate old to modern: It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men.
target: It is the most difficult to understand dog That ever stayed with men.

orig: translate old to modern: I shall be pinched to death.
target: I shall be pinched to death.

orig: translate old to modern: O, come in, equivocator.
target: O, come in, liar.

orig: translate old to modern: in form and moving how express and admirable!
target: in form and moving, how expressive and admirable!

orig: translate old to modern: O, ’tis a parlous boy, Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.
target: Oh, he’s a dangerously clever boy—bold, quick-witted, capable.

orig: translate old to modern: Now go we in content To liberty, and not to banishment.
target: Now, we go contentedly to freedom—not banishment.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, noble lord.
target: Yes, noble lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore with frank and with uncurbèd plainness Tell us the Dauphin’s mind.
target: Therefore tell me the Dauphin’s mind frankly and without constraint.

orig: translate old to modern: Mine eyes do itch; Doth that bode weeping?
target: My eyes itch; Does that predict tears?

orig: translate old to modern: After her, after her.
target: After her, after her.

orig: translate old to modern: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.
target: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is said and done.

orig: translate old to modern: Her husband, knave.
target: Her husband, you rascal.

orig: translate old to modern: Before me, she’s a good wench.
target: She’s a fine woman, all right.

orig: translate old to modern: I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you—      Pray you, content.
target: Goneril, you know how much I love you, but still I have to say— Shush, please.

orig: translate old to modern: I will preach to thee.
target: I’ll read you a sermon.

orig: translate old to modern: By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber, ay’ll de gud service, or I’ll lig i' th' grund for it, ay, or go to death.
target: I swear by the mass, before I close my eyes to go to sleep, I’ll put in some good fighting, or I’ll lie in the ground dead.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once Had not concluded all.—He wakes.
target: It’s a wonder you didn’t lose your life and your mind all at once.—He’s waking up.

orig: translate old to modern: No woman’s heart So big, to hold so much.
target: No woman’s heart is big enough to hold all my love.

orig: translate old to modern: He goes before me, and still dares me on; When I come where he calls, then he is gone.
target: He went before me, and still dares me to fight; When I get to where he’s calling from, he’s gone.

orig: translate old to modern: No, I’ll not weep.
target: Well, I won’t.

orig: translate old to modern: Sinful Macduff, They were all struck for thee!
target: Sinful Macduff, They were all struck for you!

orig: translate old to modern: O, kiss me through the hole of this vile wall.
target: Oh, kiss me through the hole of this vile wall.

orig: translate old to modern: Who does he accuse?
target: Who does he accuse?

orig: translate old to modern: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.
target: I was telling you to go after her, woo her, confront her.

orig: translate old to modern: Aroint thee, witch!” the rump-fed ronyon cries.
target: the fat, sloppy woman cries.

orig: translate old to modern: You are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice; even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion.
target: You are now only fallen in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice; even as some one would beat his defenseless dog to scare an imperious lion.

orig: translate old to modern: I will, my lord.
target: I will, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: He’s dead.
target: He’s dead.

orig: translate old to modern: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part— I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
target: If you hadn’t shown up on cue, my lord, Lord Hastings was going to take your part—I mean, he was going to speak for you—in the crowning of the king.

orig: translate old to modern: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes a while, And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
target: Can you keep your heavy eyes open awhile, And play a song or two on your harp?

orig: translate old to modern: What's thy pleasure?
target: What's your pleasure?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis like a demi-cannon.
target: It’s like a cannon.

orig: translate old to modern: Sirrah, go see what trumpet ’tis that sounds.
target: Go, lad, and find out what the trumpet’s sounding for.

orig: translate old to modern: O rejoice Beyond a common joy!
target: O, rejoice Beyond a common joy, and set it down With gold on lasting pillars.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, let that rest.
target: Well, it doesn’t matter anymore.

orig: translate old to modern: He shall, sir, an't please him.
target: He shall, sir, if it pleases him.

orig: translate old to modern: He’s friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.
target: You say he’s friendly with Caesar, healthy, and free.

orig: translate old to modern: No, not for all the world.
target: No, not for all the world.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll not believe't.
target: I'll not believe it.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?
target: Shall any other man be killed besides Caesar?

orig: translate old to modern: If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus Should with his lion gait walk the whole world, He might return to vasty Tartar back And tell the legions “I can never win A soul so easy as that Englishman’s.” Oh, how hast thou with jealousy infected The sweetness of affiance!
target: The demon who seduced you could stride the world over with the proud gait of a lion, could return to hell and tell the devil’s legions, “I will never win another soul as easily as I won that Englishman’s.” How you have poisoned my faith in people!

orig: translate old to modern: I am woe for't, sir.
target: I am very sorry about it, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou thinkest I am in sport.
target: You think I’m kidding.

orig: translate old to modern: There's a bargain made.
target: It’s a deal.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, farewell.
target: Farewell, farewell.

orig: translate old to modern: He has kill'd me, Mother.
target: He has killed me, mother.

orig: translate old to modern: Too well, too well.
target: Only too well.

orig: translate old to modern: Never make denial.
target: Don’t even think about refusing.

orig: translate old to modern: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
target: Will my daughter be a good musician, do you think?

orig: translate old to modern: What have I done, that thou darest wag thy tongue In noise so rude against me?
target: What have I done, that you dare scream at me So loudly and rudely?

orig: translate old to modern: O, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing.
target: O, yes; as summer flies are in the swamps, That move quickly even with blowing.

orig: translate old to modern: Villainy, villainy, villainy!
target: Villainy, villainy, villainy!

orig: translate old to modern: Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the duke.
target: So, kneel down, and beg mercy of the Duke.

orig: translate old to modern: If arguing make us sweat, The proof of it will turn to redder drops.
target: If arguing makes us sweat, The proof of it will turn to redder drops.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, my lords.
target: Goodbye, gentlemen.

orig: translate old to modern: By your patience, no.
target: No, I’d rather you stayed here.

orig: translate old to modern: By Gis and by Saint Charity, Alack, and fie for shame!
target: By God and by Saint Charity, Pity, and for shame, for shame!

orig: translate old to modern: Must she not then be answered?
target: Shouldn’t she just accept that?

orig: translate old to modern: That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians, Wherein my letters, praying on his side, Because I knew the man, were slighted off.
target: That you’ve wronged me shows in this action: You’ve condemned and punished Lucius Pella For taking bribes from the Sardians here, And my letters, taking his side Because I knew the man, were blown off.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, my good lord.
target: Here, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, I will fight with him upon this theme Until my eyelids will no longer wag.
target: Why, I will fight with him upon this theme Until my eyelids will no longer blink.

orig: translate old to modern: The world's a huge thing; it is a great price For a final vice.
target: The world's a huge thing; it is a great price to pay For a small sin.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, that they do, my lord, Hercules and his load too.
target: Yes, they do, my lord, Hercules and his load too.

orig: translate old to modern: Gallants, I am not as I have been.
target: Gentleman, I am not the same man I was before.

orig: translate old to modern: If this which he avouches does appear, There is nor flying hence nor tarrying here.
target: If this which he swears does appear, There is no flying from here or wasting time here.

orig: translate old to modern: what have we here?
target: what have we here?

orig: translate old to modern: What should that bode?
target: What do you think that means?

orig: translate old to modern: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
target: You could just as easily say that a king sleeps near a beggar if the beggar lives near him, or that the church is supported by your drum because it “stands by” your drum.

orig: translate old to modern: O, damn her!
target: O, damn her!

orig: translate old to modern: Dolabella!
target: Dolabella!

orig: translate old to modern: Speak, for my heart is full.
target: Speak, because my heart is full.

orig: translate old to modern: Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father’s death.
target: Innocent sweethearts, you have no idea who’s responsible for your father’s death.

orig: translate old to modern: Did you see him?
target: Did you see him?

orig: translate old to modern: I do not set my life at a pin's fee; And for my soul, what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?
target: I don’t value my life at the price of a pin, And as for my soul, what can it do to that, Being a thing that is immortal as it is?

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!
target: Oh, I remember that very clearly!

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee let me have it.
target: Can I have some?

orig: translate old to modern: I, Beyond all limit of what else i'th’ world, Do love, prize, honour you.
target: I, Beyond all limit of whatever else in the world, Do love, prize, honor you.

orig: translate old to modern: I cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.
target: I cannot blame you now for weeping.

orig: translate old to modern: Now heaven help him!
target: Heaven help him!

orig: translate old to modern: See, Caesar!
target: Look around you, Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes the man you mean.
target: Here comes the man himself.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
target: Because then I’d have to shed an ounce or two of your impudent blood.

orig: translate old to modern: Stands he or sits he?
target: Is he standing or sitting?

orig: translate old to modern: It would cost you a groaning to take off my edge.
target: It would cost you a night in bed to take the edge off me.

orig: translate old to modern: Added to these, Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen, Eight thousand and four hundred, of the which, Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights.
target: Add to these eight thousand four hundred knights, squires, and brave gentlemen, five hundred of whom were given the title of knight only yesterday.

orig: translate old to modern: Never did faithful subject more rejoice At the discovery of most dangerous treason Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself, Prevented from a damnèd enterprise.
target: No faithful subject ever rejoiced more at the discovery of most dangerous treason than I now rejoice that I was thwarted in a damnable undertaking.

orig: translate old to modern: A good and virtuous nature may recoil In an imperial charge.
target: A good and virtuous nature may recoil In an charge by a king.

orig: translate old to modern: Hold, worthy lady, hold!
target: Stop, brave lady, stop!

orig: translate old to modern: There is Siward's son And many unrough youths, that even now Protest their first of manhood.
target: There is Siward's son And many youths without beards which now Affirm they are beginning manhood.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail, brave friend!
target: Hail, brave friend!

orig: translate old to modern: I think this tale would win my daughter too.
target: I think this tale would win my daughter too.

orig: translate old to modern: Can virtue hide itself?
target: Can a good thing hide itself?

orig: translate old to modern: Very ill, too.
target: I’m very sick, too.

orig: translate old to modern: Use every man after his desert, and who shall 'scape whipping?
target: Use every man according to his class, and who should escape whipping?

orig: translate old to modern: Were they not forced with those that should be ours, We might have met them dareful, beard to beard, And beat them backward home.
target: If they were not reinforced by those troops that should be ours, We might have met them boldly, beard to beard, And beat them backward where they came from.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me, Othello.
target: Tell me, Othello.

orig: translate old to modern: God quit you in His mercy.
target: May God in His mercy forgive you.

orig: translate old to modern: It sorts well with your fierceness.
target: The name suits your fierceness.

orig: translate old to modern: I have some rights of memory in this kingdom, Which now, to claim my vantage doth invite me.
target: I have some rights of past history in this kingdom, Which now invites me to claim my place.

orig: translate old to modern: As I stood here below, methought his eyes Were two full moons.
target: From down here, I thought his eyes looked like full moons.

orig: translate old to modern: What is thy name?
target: What is your name?

orig: translate old to modern: That now Sweno, the Norways’ king, craves composition; Nor would we deign him burial of his men Till he disbursed, at Saint Colme's Inch, Ten thousand dollars to our general use.
target: Then Sweno, Norwegian king, wanted a treaty; We would not agree to the burial of his men Until he paid us, at Saint Colme's island, Ten thousand dollars to our general use.

orig: translate old to modern: Not sad, my lord.
target: I’m not sad, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!
target: How sweet the moonlight sleeps on this bank!

orig: translate old to modern: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears.
target: Find him, Titinius, while I go ahead to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweets to the sweet!
target: Sweets to the sweet.

orig: translate old to modern: Let them come before Master Constable.
target: Have them come in front of the master constable.

orig: translate old to modern: My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?
target: My Lord Constable, are those stars or suns I saw on the armor in your tent tonight?

orig: translate old to modern: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
target: Look, here comes just the man we were looking for.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
target: I’m not sick, if Brutus have any exploit Worthy of the name of honor in hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, what cry is that?
target: Alas, what cry is that?

orig: translate old to modern: Here’s to Caesar.
target: Here’s to Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: I hate a drunken rogue.
target: I hate no-good drunks.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I care not for their names.
target: Nah, I don’t care what their

orig: translate old to modern: Why have you stol’n upon us thus?
target: Then why did you travel so quietly?

orig: translate old to modern: You have said, but whether wisely or no, let the forest judge.
target: All right, you’ve had your say, but we’ll let the forest judge whether or not you spoke wisely.

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, fie, fie, pah, pah!—Give me an ounce of civet, good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination.
target: Give me an aphrodisiac, pharmacist.

orig: translate old to modern: tis strange.
target: It is strange.

orig: translate old to modern: I do not think there is any such woman.
target: I don’t think there is any such woman.

orig: translate old to modern: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill!
target: Error in the bill, sir, error in the bill!

orig: translate old to modern: Well, my lord.
target: Well, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
target: A plague on the tyrant that I serve!

orig: translate old to modern: I never may believe These antique fables, nor these fairy toys.
target: I never may believe These antique fables, or these fairy toys.

orig: translate old to modern: I do remember.
target: I remember.

orig: translate old to modern: I dare do all that may become a man; Who dares do more is none.
target: I dare to do all that may become a man; Who dares to do more is not a man.

orig: translate old to modern: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.
target: No one may be bolder than my Lord Hastings.

orig: translate old to modern: As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for ’t.
target: You have my word as a gentleman that I’ll always be grateful to you.

orig: translate old to modern: Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.
target: On my knee, I humbly ask your blessing.

orig: translate old to modern: Yare!
target: Quick!

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio, And much offence too.
target: Yes, by Saint Patrick, but there is, Horatio, And much offense too.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, here!
target: Here, here!

orig: translate old to modern: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.
target: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

orig: translate old to modern: Seems, madam?
target: Seem?”, madam!

orig: translate old to modern: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
target: And I swear to God he’s very smart.

orig: translate old to modern: These fellows have some soul, And such a one do I profess myself.
target: These fellows have some soul; And someone like that is how I am.

orig: translate old to modern: Who calls on Hamlet?
target: Who calls Hamlet?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, how now, Stephano?
target: Why, how is it now, Stephano!

orig: translate old to modern: Stop her there!
target: Stop her!

orig: translate old to modern: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose— Help me away, dear Charmian!
target: I’m sorry to have to say this— Help me away from here, dear Charmian!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, for that too.
target: Why, for that too.

orig: translate old to modern: What, if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleas'd to give ten thousand ducats To have it ban'd?
target: What if a rat troubles my house, And I am happy to give ten thousand dollars To have it captured?

orig: translate old to modern: Behold the ordnance on their carriages, With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur.
target: Take in the wheeled canons with their deadly gaping mouths trained on the walled city of Harfleur.

orig: translate old to modern: By your most gracious pardon, I sing but after you.
target: Pardon me, but I’m just repeating what you yourself have said.

orig: translate old to modern: More, Domitius: My lord desires you presently.
target: Another thing, Domitius: Antony wants to see you now.

orig: translate old to modern: I have done nothing but in care of thee, Of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter, who Art ignorant of what thou art, naught knowing Of whence I am, nor that I am more better Than Prospero, master of a full poor cell, And thy no greater father.
target: I have done nothing except to protect you, Protect you, my dear one, you, my daughter, who Doesn’t know what you are, not knowing Where I come from or that I better Than Prospero, master of a full, poor dwelling, And your not so proud father.

orig: translate old to modern: Scarcity and want shall shun you, Ceres’ blessing so is on you.
target: Scarcity and want shall ignore you; Ceres' blessing so be on you.

orig: translate old to modern: All this?
target: All this?

orig: translate old to modern: O, 'tis most sweet When in one line two crafts directly meet.
target: O, it is most sweet, When you can kill two birds with one stone.

orig: translate old to modern: But, adieu!
target: But, goodbye!

orig: translate old to modern: I thank you for your pains.
target: Thanks for your trouble.

orig: translate old to modern: I wish your Worship well.
target: I wish you well.

orig: translate old to modern: What men daily do, not knowing what they do!
target: The things men do daily, not knowing what they’re doing!

orig: translate old to modern: Tis a fearful odds.
target: These are frightening odds.

orig: translate old to modern: Give us the place alone.
target: Everyone, please leave us alone for a moment.

orig: translate old to modern: O excellent!
target: Oh excellent!

orig: translate old to modern: Wash your hands, put on your nightgown; look not so pale.
target: Wash your hands, put on your nightgown; look not so pale.

orig: translate old to modern: fool!
target: fool!

orig: translate old to modern: Come on!
target: Come on.

orig: translate old to modern: Gertrude, do not drink.
target: Gertrude, don’t drink.

orig: translate old to modern: My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
target: My reputation, Iago, my reputation!

orig: translate old to modern: In me ’tis villainy, In thee ’t had been good service.
target: For you to do it would be good service.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, I say!
target: my lord, I say!

orig: translate old to modern: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.
target: There’s a farmer here who won’t leave without seeing your Highness.

orig: translate old to modern: It is very meet, The Lord Bassanio live an upright life; For, having such a blessing in his lady, He finds the joys of heaven here on earth; And, if on earth he do not mean it, then In reason he should never come to heaven.
target: It is very proper The Lord Bassanio live an upright life, Because, having such a blessing in his lady, He finds the joys of heaven here on earth; And if he doesn’t merit it on earth, It stands to reason he should never enter heaven.

target: We’ll meet at the duke's oak.

orig: translate old to modern: O horror, horror, horror!
target: O horror, horror, horror!

orig: translate old to modern: Do thou meet me presently at the harbor.
target: Meet me right away at the harbor.

orig: translate old to modern: Away, away, for he is coming hither!
target: Look out, he’s coming!

orig: translate old to modern: Come on; in this there can be no dismay, My ships come home a month before the day.
target: Come on; in this transaction, there can be no fear; My ships come home a month before the due date.

orig: translate old to modern: Then, tell me, Who's the next heir of Naples?
target: Then tell me, Who's the next heir of Naples?

orig: translate old to modern: If knife, drugs, serpents, have Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
target: If knives, poison, or snakes have edge, effect, or venom, I am safe from that fate.

orig: translate old to modern: Who else should be?
target: Who else should it be?

orig: translate old to modern: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
target: An old Italian fox is never that generous, my boy.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, sooth; and so do you.
target: Yes, truly, and so do you.

orig: translate old to modern: Approach, ye Furies fell.
target: Approach, you vicious fates!

orig: translate old to modern: Hum!
target: Hum!

orig: translate old to modern: What, must our mouths be cold?
target: What, must our voices be ignored?

orig: translate old to modern: I am fear'd in field and town.
target: The field and town are afraid of me.

orig: translate old to modern: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly.
target: No, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: If it be man’s work, I’ll do ’t.
target: If it’s work for a man, I’ll do it.

orig: translate old to modern: It shall be done.
target: It shall be done.

orig: translate old to modern: This nothing's more than matter.
target: This “nothing” is more than just a story.

orig: translate old to modern: They are weary?
target: These are tricks.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis noble spoken.
target: Spoken like a gentleman.

orig: translate old to modern: Utter my thoughts?
target: Speak my thoughts?

orig: translate old to modern: Others there are, Who, trimm'd in forms and visages of duty, Keep yet their hearts attending on themselves, And throwing but shows of service on their lords Do well thrive by them; and when they have lined their coats Do themselves homage.
target: There are others who, dressed in uniforms and faces of duty, that keep their hearts attending on themselves; And, throwing only shows of service to their lords, Thrive well by them, and when they have lined their coats, Do themselves homage.

orig: translate old to modern: By my troth, I am sick.
target: God, I’m really sick.

orig: translate old to modern: A very fine one.
target: He’s a stylish man.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, get thee in Yaughan; fetch me a stoup of liquor.
target: Go, get you to Johann, bring me a mug of whiskey.

orig: translate old to modern: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
target: My friends, are you all Lady Olivia’s servants?

orig: translate old to modern: I want more uncles here to welcome me.
target: I want more uncles here to welcome me.

orig: translate old to modern: In a false quarrel there is no true valor.
target: There’s no bravery in an unfair fight.

orig: translate old to modern: Some god direct my judgment!
target: Some god direct my judgment!

orig: translate old to modern: I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.
target: Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland, I arrest you for high treason.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll to my charge.
target: I’ll go and join my men.

orig: translate old to modern: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best belovèd and approvèd friend, Hortensio.
target: I’m off to visit my friends in Padua—particularly my best friend Hortensio.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me a kiss.
target: Give me a kiss.

orig: translate old to modern: Right joyous are we to behold your face, Most worthy brother England.
target: We rejoice to see you, most worthy brother of England.

orig: translate old to modern: How, sir, how?
target: What, sir, how!

orig: translate old to modern: Thanks, good my countryman.
target: Thanks, my good countryman.

orig: translate old to modern: Say to the King I would attend his leisure For a few words.
target: Tell the king that I wish to speak with him, For a few words.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, and bring them.
target: Bring them right in.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not trouble you As yet to question you about your fortunes.— Give us some music, and, good cousin, sing.
target: I won’t trouble you yet with questions about your situation.—Some music, please, and, good friend, sing.

orig: translate old to modern: Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn To do this piece of ruthless butchery, Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs, Melted with tenderness and mild compassion, Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story.
target: Dighton and Forrest, whom I hired to perform the butchery, are used to killing people, the bloody dogs.

orig: translate old to modern: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
target: I tell you, I feel very jolly remembering such a beautiful dream.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, that your Highness knew my heart in this: I never loved my brother in my life.
target: I wish your Highness knew my true feelings in this matter: I have never in my life loved my brother.

orig: translate old to modern: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die; And for her sake do I rear up her boy; And for her sake I will not part with him.
target: But she, because she was mortal, died giving birth to the boy; And, for her sake, I am raising him, And, for her sake, I will not part with him.

orig: translate old to modern: Let her have your voices.
target: Let her have your votes.

orig: translate old to modern: Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so?
target: Should I have answered Caius Cassius if he asked me?

orig: translate old to modern: It came even from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!
target: It was just removed from from the heart of—oh, she’s dead!

orig: translate old to modern: And so, adieu.
target: And so, good-bye.

orig: translate old to modern: Darkness and devils!
target: Hell and damnation!

orig: translate old to modern: Why is this 'impawned,' as you call it?
target: Why is this all wagered, as you call it?

orig: translate old to modern: My mother had a maid call'd Barbara; She was in love, and he she loved proved mad And did forsake her.
target: My mother had a maid called Barbara; She was in love; and the man she loved went crazy And left her.

orig: translate old to modern: But come, I'll tell thee all my whole device When I am in my coach, which stays for us At the park gate; and therefore haste away, For we must measure twenty miles to-day.
target: But come, I'll tell you all about my whole plan When I am in my coach, which waits for us At the park gate; and so hurry, Because we must travel twenty miles today.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father Was Duke of Milan, and his only heir And princess no worse issued.
target: Your mother was a piece of virtue, and She said you were my daughter: and your father Was Duke of Milan and his only heir A princess — born no less.

orig: translate old to modern: What do you here?
target: What are you doing here?

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
target: Shall I be afraid when a madman stares at me?

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, good Salisbury, and good luck go with thee.
target: Farewell, good Salisbury; and may good luck go with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad.
target: I beg you, daughter, don’t make me crazy.

orig: translate old to modern: See, whether their basest metal be not moved; They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.
target: See whether they’ll really do what you suggested; Their guilt made them vanish in silence.

orig: translate old to modern: You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia.
target: You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia.

orig: translate old to modern: The fiend is at mine elbow, and tempts me; saying to me,—Gobbo, Launcelot Gobbo, good Launcelot, or good Gobbo, or good Launcelot Gobbo, use your legs, take the start, run away.—My conscience says, no; take heed, honest Launcelot; take heed, honest Gobbo; or, (as aforesaid) honest Launcelot Gobbo; do not run: scorn running with thy heels: well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack; Via!
target: The devil is at my elbow and tempts me, saying to me, “Gobbo, Launcelot Gobbo, good Launcelot” or “good Gobbo” or “good Launcelot Gobbo, use your legs, get going, run away.” My conscience says, “No; be careful, honest Launcelot, be careful, honest Gobbo” or, as I said before, “honest Launcelot Gobbo, don’t run; scorn running with your heels.” Well, the most courageous devil tells me to pack.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it against me.
target: I’ll meet all your attacks, even if you come charging at me with a lance at full gallop.

orig: translate old to modern: And this way have you well expounded it.
target: And in this way, you have explained it very well.

orig: translate old to modern: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.
target: Mark Antony, here, take Caesar's body.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, most heedfully.
target: Sir, very carefully.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis a villain, sir, I do not love to look on.
target: It is a villain, sir, that I don’t like to look at.

orig: translate old to modern: But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master’s, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
target: This is for your master’s sake, not mine.

orig: translate old to modern: Myself?
target: Myself?

orig: translate old to modern: I marvel our mild husband Not met us on the way.
target: I’m surprised my bland husband didn’t meet me on the way here.

orig: translate old to modern: No, not tonight.
target: No, not tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: A halter gratis; nothing else, for God's sake!
target: A free rope with a nooses; nothing else, for God's sake!

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll follow this good man, and go with you; And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
target: I’ll follow the priest and go with you; and after I’ve sworn to be faithful, I’ll be faithful forever.

orig: translate old to modern: Hark you, Guildenstern, and you too—at each ear a hearer!
target: Listen, Guildenstern, and you too, with each ear.

orig: translate old to modern: The man is innocent.
target: The man hasn’t done anything wrong.

orig: translate old to modern: Besides, it were a mock Apt to be render'd, for some one to say “Break up the Senate till another time, When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.” If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper “Lo, Caesar is afraid”?
target: Besides, it’s might be Interpreted as silly, because someone says "Break up the Senate until another time, When Caesar's wife shall have better dreams.

orig: translate old to modern: Hero that is dead!
target: The Hero that died!

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, thy vile lady!
target: Oh, your contemptible lady!

orig: translate old to modern: She hath prevented me.
target: Well, she got away.

orig: translate old to modern: I protest I love thee.
target: I swear, I love you.

orig: translate old to modern: Think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it.
target: If you can think of a more awful title, I’ll call her that.

orig: translate old to modern: Montano and myself being in speech, There comes a fellow crying out for help, And Cassio following him with determined sword, To execute upon him.
target: Montano and myself were talking, and There comes a fellow crying out for help, With Cassio following him with determined sword, To kill him.

orig: translate old to modern: And I have heard Apollodorus carried—                                                                               What, I pray you?
target: I heard that Apollodorus carried—   What did he carry, please?

orig: translate old to modern: I must obey.
target: I have to obey.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, I have eat none yet.
target: But I haven’t eaten anything yet.

orig: translate old to modern: Run one before And let the Queen know of our gests.
target: One of you run to the Queen with the news.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor I.
target: Me too.

orig: translate old to modern: To her, widow!
target: You tell her, widow!

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, we fear the worst.
target: Come, come, we’re worrying about the worst-case scenario.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome hither.
target: Welcome here.

orig: translate old to modern: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing To tell him his commandment is fulfill'd That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
target: The ears that should give us hearing can’t hear, To tell him his order is obeyed, That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.

orig: translate old to modern: We are blessèd in the change.
target: We are fortunate in the change.

orig: translate old to modern: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong For the whole world.
target: Curse me, if I would do such a wrong thing for the whole world.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor I.
target: Me neither.

orig: translate old to modern: But if she cannot love you, sir?
target: But if she can’t love you, sir?

orig: translate old to modern: Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
target: My lady, will you have a dance with me?

orig: translate old to modern: A noble duke, in nature As in name.
target: A duke who is noble in name and character.

orig: translate old to modern: So he laughed and let me go.
target: He laughed at that and let me go.

orig: translate old to modern: The glow-worm shows the matin to be near And 'gins to pale his uneffectual fire.
target: The glowworm shows the morning is near, And he begins to put out his ineffective fire.
